PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Discrimination against Women

To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
(5) Subjecting Australia to monitoring and control by foreign nations.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 22 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 124 citizens), Lewis (from 10 citizens), Robert Ray (from 59 citizens) and Scott (from 378 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women is a threat to the independence and well-being of Australia and her families.
Your petitioners therefore pray the Government not to ratify the said Convention, Believing That:

1. The Convention treats mothering as a second class calling and is discriminatory against the stable family unit, the single income family, and mothers who want a free choice to care for their children at home.

2. The establishment and development of a network of child care facilities ( Article 11 (c) ) will only increase maternal deprivation on the part of children , and place further financial burdens upon the government.
3. The forcing of more women into the workforce can only be detrimental to Australia at this time of high unemployment.
4. Australia will make herself subject to the International Court of Justice and no longer be a properly autonomous nation.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing that men and women are equal but different, convinced that Australia can provide equal opportunity for all citizens without foreign treaties, concerned that ratifying the UN Discrimination Convention would give a Communist-dominated international committee the power to judge Australia's laws, humbly petition that your Honourable House will not ratify the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and we will always thus petition.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
(1) Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

(2) Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
(3) Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

(4) Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme, Girrawheen
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Division of Moore respectfully showeth:

That there is great need for the establishment of a new Community Youth Support Scheme project in the Subdivision of Girrawheen, because of the high level of youth unemployment in this subdivision, in order that the CYSS project can provide a range of activities which develop the skills, abilities and self reliance of unemployed young people resident in the Subdivision of Girrawheen.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
That proposals for the establishment of a new Community Youth Support Scheme project in the Subdivision of Girrawheen be granted favourable and prompt attention by this Parliament and its Ministers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submits that:

Although many occurrences of sexual harassment in the workforce have been reported to various State government authorities, such as the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity, the real incidence of sexual intimidation in employment will not be known, or countered, until a national policy towards sexual harassment is determined and implemented.
We therefore submit that:

1. The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation be commissioned to conduct a nation-wide study of discrimination based on sex, both in the private sector and the Public Service, with a view to advising the Government on the development of national policy.
2. The major priority of such a study should be to determine a legally- enforceable definition of sexual harassment.

3. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should bring forward in Parliament legislation, arising from such a study, to outlaw discrimination and intimidation in employment based on sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Mart Niklus
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That we are deeply concerned for the well-being of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist who is in ill health and imprisoned in solitary confinement in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36 in Siberia.
(2) That Mr Mart Niklus has been imprisoned as a 'prisoner of conscience' for the non-violent exercise of his beliefs and is denied visiting and communication rights.

(3) That the Australian Government give its support to any initiatives in this case by Amnesty International which has adopted Mr Mart Niklus. Amnesty International believes he has committed no real crime and has never used or advocated the use of violence.
(4) That we urge the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly release Mr Mart Niklus and grant him a passport and exit visa.
(5) That in its representations to the Government of the Soviet Union advise that the Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of West Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That, because the aforesaid U.N. Convention which has been ratified and is about to be made the subject of lawful application by Parliament, contains articles which intend to force a re-structuring of our society in that:
(a) Women will have equal responsibilities as well as rights in all areas of society.
(b) Role changing between sexes in society and family, with revision of text books, school programmes, and teaching methods to that end.

(c) Provision of net-works of child care centres for infants, and that the implication of all these changes will produce an uni-sex society, eliminating the traditional family as the basic unit of Australian society.
Your petitioners therefore humbly beg the Parliament to:

(a) Oppose the recommendations of the Bill introduced to Parliament by Senator Ryan on 2nd June, 1983, and any other subsequent Bill intending to force such uni-sex and anti-family legislation as above in (a), (b) and (c).
(b) To set up a Select Committee to conduct a Wide-ranging public enquiry into ways and means of strengthening and supporting the traditional concept of the family as the basic unit of society.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting , I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Government for the introduction of a discriminatory wine impost and notes:
(1) That the 1983 Budget imposition of an excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia;

(2) That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occuring is inequitable as returns to producers will not be received until the product is sold several years in the future;
(3) That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent;

(4) That producers of quality ports, sheries, muscats and other fortified wines will be encouraged either to withdraw from the market completely, thereby restricting consumer choice, or to reduce the maturation for such products, thereby reducing the quality;
(5) That this excise will increase the costs of production of fortified wines for export, further disadvantaging Australian producers on overseas markets;

(6) That the consequential reduction of fortified wine sales will be reflected in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers for these purposes, particularly from grapegrowers in the Riverland region of South Australia, the Leeton- Griffith district of New South Wales and Sunraysia in Victoria;
(7) That this will increase the hardship suffered by grapegrowers in these areas causing severe economic problems in decentralised regions;

and it calls on the Government to either abolish this new impost or-at the very least-alter the payment of excise arrangements so as to only require payment when fortified wines are released for sale on the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its abhorrence and indignation at the destruction of an unarmed civilian airliner, Korean Air Lines flight 7, shot down by a Soviet military aircraft on the morning of 1 September 1983, Australian eastern standard time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This statement is currently being made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives. It relates to the tragic episode which shocked the world last week in relation to the Korean airliner. On the basis of information available to it, the Government has no doubt that Korean Air Lines flight 7, en route from Anchorage to Seoul, was shot down by a Soviet fighter aircraft early in the morning of 1 September Australian eastern standard time.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many unanswered questions surrounding this disaster. The basic ones are: How was it possible for military aircraft to fire on and destroy a civilian airliner in peace time; and why has the Soviet Union been unable or unwilling to produce a coherent, convincing and suitably regretful account of these appalling circumstances? Whatever the answer to these and to the other important question of how the airliner strayed so far off course into Soviet airspace, the simple fact is that an unarmed civilian airliner serving no military purpose was shot down by a Soviet fighter aircraft. There can be no justification for such a barbaric act. Two hundred and sixty-nine passengers and crew, including five Australians, have died.

Following this tragedy, the Government has taken action to bring to the attention of the Soviet Government its deep concern and shock and has sought a prompt and full explanation of Soviet actions. The Soviet Ambassador in Australia was called to the Department of Foreign Affairs on 2 September and requested to provide a full and proper account of the circumstances surrounding this unjustifiable act. On the same day, our Ambassador in Moscow, Mr Evans, called on the Soviet Foreign Ministry and made the same request. So far, the Soviet authorities have provided no information in response to our request. They have simply drawn our attention to statements made by the official Soviet newsagency, Tass. Apart from the fact that the statements so far issued by Tass have been totally inadequate and deliberately misleading-they have, for example, made the preposterous claim that the Korean airliner was on an intelligence mission-they are quite inappropriate as communications between governments.

The Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) have made crystal clear the Government's outrage and condemnation at what has occurred. The Government will maintain persistent and strong pressure for an adequate explanation. The Prime Minister has personally expressed our condolences to the bereaved Australian families. He has also sent a message of sympathy to President Chun Doo Hwan of the Republic of Korea, who will be paying an official visit to Australia next month. President Chun has expressed his country's appreciation of our support and sympathy.

Australia was at the forefront of those countries which called for an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss this tragedy. This took place on Friday 2 September and will resume on 6 September, United States time. The Australian acting permanent representative, Mr Joseph, expressed Australia's shock and indignation at the downing of the Korean Air Lines flight. Describing the incident as a 'massacre in the sky', Mr Joseph said:

Australia joins with other members of the international community in demanding an immediate and full accounting from the Soviet authorities. We have put this request bilaterally and I repeat it here today in a multilateral context. The explanations so far emanating from Moscow about the episode are in our view entirely inadequate. There has been a refusal thus far either to acknowledge responsibility or even to extend a convincing expression of regret for the action. This is deplorable. We appeal to the Soviet Union, if the Soviet authorities give in to the instinct to cover up, it will only confirm the worst fears of those who suspect them most, with repercussions across the spectrum of international relations.
Mr Joseph went on to say:

In this regard, Mr President, I must say that one cannot but feel profoundly disturbed by the latest TASS statement which was read out to the Council earlier this afternoon by the delegation of the USSR. We see no element of contrition in the statement. It amounts, at least on first reading, to blaming the victims themselves. I would remind the Soviet delegation that some of those victims were Australian citizens and I would say firmly on the behalf of these victims, now deceased, that they were entirely blameless in this appalling episode. We reject this latest attempted evasion of responsibility.

I believe that the Senate would fully support the stance taken by this Government before the United Nations. This incident is one of the gravest concern to every nation. It is incompatible with accepted norms of civilised behaviour between nations and contrary to principles of international law. Moreover, it has very serious consequences for the safety of air navigation.

Sadly this incident is not the first of its kind. Honourable senators will recall that in 1978 Soviet fighters opened fire on and forced to land another KAL flight, also with some loss of life. Earlier, in 1973 a Libyan aircraft strayed unwittingly over the Sinai Desert and was shot down by Israeli fighters with a loss of over 100 passengers and crew. That action was taken only after the pilot acknowledged, but did not heed, the warnings and signals given by the fighters. Furthermore, the Israeli Government promptly provided details of the incident, issued a statement expressing 'deep sorrow' at the loss of life and announced ex gratia payments of compensation to the families of those killed in explicit deference to humanitarian considerations.

Mr President, there is a grim irony in the fact that the Soviet representative to an emergency session of the International Civil Aviation Organisation, ICAO, in February 1973 described that incident as a 'criminal act of international terrorism' and said that 'ICAO could not remain aloof from the barbaric act committed by Israel.' In 1955 compensation was also offered by the Bulgarian Government after its air force had shot down an Israeli airliner in Bulgarian airspace killing 64 passengers and crew. The Bulgarians offered to pay compensation to the families of those killed, to punish 'those responsible for the catastrophe' and to take measures to prevent a repetition of such incidents. There are, therefore precedents for the kind of response which the international community has every right now to expect of the Soviet Union.

Mr President, there is another dimension to this tragedy, to which I would like to draw the attention of the Senate. The incident is a reminder of the consequences of continued hostility and lack of communication and dialogue in the Korean peninsula. Australia has recognised two states and two governments on the Korean peninsula since 1974. Other western nations which have relations with the Republic of Korea, South Korea, have made clear that they would be prepared to recognise the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, North Korea, if the DPRK and its friends, including the Soviet Union, would come to terms with the reality that there has existed in South Korea for over 30 years a sovereign government, the Republic of Korea.

It is our firm conviction that the continuing failure of the Soviet Union and others to recognise that reality, while attempting to deny the Republic of Korea its legitimate place in the international community and its rights in international law has contributed to the circumstances in which this appalling action has taken place.

Mr President, Cabinet discussed this matter yesterday and examined possible future action which Australia, together with other nations principally affected, might take. In its deliberations the Government was mindful of the calm and deeply moving words of Mr Ray Grenfell, the brother of one of the Australian victims, who after expressing his shock and disbelief at the destruction of an unarmed passenger aircraft said: 'But we don't believe there should be any further violence or retribution-one act like that does not deserve another act'.

The Government has decided to continue to press the Soviet authorities for a full accounting of their actions. We are examining what steps might be taken to strengthen the safety of international civil aviation. We are supporting the convening of an extraordinary meeting of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organisation in Montreal next week. There we will seek a full accounting by the Soviet Union and a thorough impartial investigation in accordance with the Chicago Convention.

The shooting down of the Korean aircraft was a clear infringement of customary international law and of the principles underlying the 1944 Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation, to which the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is a party. It is open to the Government, under international law, to claim compensation from the USSR for the loss of Australian lives. We are giving close consideration to this possibility. Obviously any amount of compensation will not recompense the grief of those families who have lost loved ones in this disaster.

The Government regards this tragedy as an affront to the international community. As a result, Australia will seek to co-ordinate its response as widely as possible with other countries and particularly with the countries of the Asia-Pacific region. In this connection, the Prime Minister spoke with the United States Secretary of State, George Shultz, on 5 September and has confirmed that our attitude to this disaster is closely consistent with that of the United States. President Reagan's strong, clear and measured statement this morning expresses the profound concern and abhorrence felt by all civilised countries at what has occurred, while keeping open the channels of communication essential to preserve international security.

Mr President, the Soviet Union is now seeking to evade its responsibilities, to shift the blame, and to categorise the justified international outrage at its action as confected indignation for propaganda purposes. The Government reiterates that the Soviet Government must provide a full and adequate account of this tragedy. I am sure that the Senate will join me in calling on the USSR to cease hiding behind evasive statements and to accept its responsibilities before the international community for the tragic consequences of its action.
Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion arising from this statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate- (1) Expresses Australia's shock and indignation at the totally unjustified destruction of a Korean Airlines Boeing 747 by Soviet fighter aircraft;
(2) Extends its deepest sympathy to the families of the Australian and other victims;
(3) Calls upon the USSR to give a full, truthful, prompt and appropriately regretful account of this tragic episode;
(4) Urges the international community to take measures to prevent the recurrence of such a tragedy; and
(5) Supports the response of the Australian Government as outlined in the foregoing statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I support generally the views put forward by the Government and I support in general terms the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). However, I wish to extend somewhat the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out paragraph (5), insert the following new paragraphs:

'(5) while supporting the response of the Australian Government to date, as outlined in the foregoing statement, requests the Government to formulate further measures that could be taken in the event of the Soviet Union failing to respond to the request in paragraph (3) and to press immediately for just compensation for the families affected by this disaster; and
(6) condemns the Soviet Union for its barbaric act'.

In moving the amendment the Opposition expresses the hope that the Government will feel able to accept it in recognition of the abhorrent behaviour of the Soviet Union, behaviour which is described in the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as barbaric. Should this not be the case we would regret the rejection but we would not wish to divide on the matter because it is a matter on which we think it is important that the Senate should adopt a unanimous response. In speaking on behalf of the Opposition I wish to make the same statement which is being made on behalf of the Opposition in the other place by the honourable member for Kooyong, Mr Peacock.

The Opposition joins with the Government in condemning the Soviet Union for the shooting down of a South Korean Air Lines aircraft and the tragic loss of life caused by this callous act. This barbaric and savage action was both inhumane and illegal. It was a senseless and impulsive act of murder which will cast a dark shadow over the Soviet Union and its credibility in the international community. It has shown the Soviet Union to be governed by leaders who place little value on human life. That may already have been revealed by their behaviour in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Afghanistan. It may already have been revealed in the treatment of political dissidents. But there could be no clearer example of the Soviet Union's callous disregard for human life than in the shooting down of an unarmed, civilian aircraft with 269 people on board. This incident tested the value the Soviet Government places on human life.

It is acknowledged that the South Korean aircraft strayed into Soviet territory . It must be understood that that territory is of great military sensitivity to the Soviet Union. But instead of guiding the aircraft back on to its course, the Soviet authorities shamelessly murdered 269 innocent men, women and children, amongst whom were five Australians. It is cause not only for reflection but also for grave concern that a super-power with the potential to destroy mankind can over-react to a minor infringement of its air space with total indifference to humanity. Moreover, by defying international law, the Soviet action has very serious consequences for the safety of air navigation. It was a breach of the 1944 Chicago convention on international aviation. As the Prime Minister pointed out, it was contrary to the 1966 and 1973 International Civil Aviation Organisation resolutions calling on states not to intercept except as a last resort-and 'intercept' does not mean shoot down. Also it was an act of legal hypocrisy. The Soviet Union was quick to charge France with illegality when, in 1961, the French Air Force intercepted a Soviet civil aircraft flying without authorisation through French air space by firing a warning shot at it. On that occasion the Soviet Union stated:
Since when has it become a custom to identify an aircraft by opening fire . . . ?

The Soviet Government must ask itself the same question today. Mr President, the actions of the Soviet Union cannot be allowed to pass without censure. No nation , however powerful, can flout the accepted international principles of civilised behaviour with impunity. Indeed, a major power such as the Soviet Union has a very great responsibility to uphold those principles in order to guarantee a more peaceful world. For this reason, the Opposition supports the measures which the Leader of the Government has outlined to the Senate today. But the Government should formulate further measures that should be taken against the Soviet Union, if the Soviet Government fails to provide a full, truthful, prompt and regretful account of its behaviour. Of course, there is very little sign so far of its wishing to do that. In this context I mention the possibility of acting to restrict the access of Soviet cruise ships to Australian waters and the possibility of suspending bilateral trade talks with the Soviet Union. The Government also should press immediately for full and just compensation for the relatives of those killed in the disaster, as the United States Administration is doing. The fact that the Soviet Union acted illegally demands, under international law, the payment of compensation.

In line with the Government's resolution, the Opposition urges the ICAO or other appropriate institutions to take measures to prevent a recurrence of such a tragedy. Measures should also be taken within ICAO to bring the Soviet Union to account for its disregard for international air law. I join with the Government in stressing the vital importance of Australia acting in concert with other Western nations and our regional neighbours in taking measures against the USSR, if they are to be fully effective. The Opposition has noted with approval the decisions announced today by the President of the United States, and welcomes the Government's commitment to act in consultation with the United States.

In conclusion, let me repeat that the Opposition, and indeed all Australians, are saddened and horrified at the atrocity committed by the Soviet Union. It was uncompassionate and inhumane slaughter. It was a grossly irresponsible act in defiance of international law. It was an act which showed the Soviet Government to be totally indifferent to the dignity of mankind, to the point of taking lives.

Finally, let me express on behalf of the Opposition our deepest sympathy to the relatives of the Grenfell family and Miss Jan Moline, the Australians who were so tragically murdered in this recent event.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats join in the general spirit of this debate and in the views expressed in the Government's motion. We convey our sympathy to the relatives of those people of all nationalities who were killed in this tragic-one cannot call it an accident- incident, Mr President. We basically approve of the more positive nature of the amendments proposed by the Liberal Party and will support it.

SPEECH.PARA: We agree that the act was barbaric. It certainly was and we should say no less than that in describing it. As the Opposition has said in its amendment: 'We condemn the Soviet Union for its barbaric act'. We also believe that the question of compensation for the families of Australian victims should be pressed as firmly and as soon as possible. This should be, and I believe will be , done by governments all over the world on behalf of nationals who were in that aircraft. It is most important that the Soviet Union should feel the economic spur in this matter one way or another, should realise that this sort of incident cannot take place without cost; that tears, the wringing of hands and apologies and explanations which come cheap enough heaven knows, are not enough. The payment of compensation in respect of those victims should be carried out on a world-wide basis. Our part is to call for it on behalf of our citizens and leave to others calling for it on behalf of theirs.

I will not go over all the facts which have been so laboriously put over the last few days and the rather cryptic nature of the circumstances that led to the incident. Aircraft are terribly vulnerable, yet tens of thousands, possibly hundreds of thousands, of people travel in them every day. The loss of lives in this incident becomes an act of peculiar brutality in view of the vulnerability of the people who travel in aircraft. They have no chance of escape whatsoever. I think that is what made people feel that this incident was so abhorrent. Yet this is a world which is becoming increasingly more brutal. What we have witnessed here is only a part of that brutality and I think it has to be recognised by all citizens of good intent that the world is not becoming a better place, rather a worse place, and fast.

It is a fact that the number of civilian casualties has increased substantially in each successive war of the last century. A nuclear war would cause monstrously more casualties of innocent civilians. In fact, it would probably kill more babies and children of tender years than would perhaps the strength of all the armies in the world. If we are talking about brutality, have we any right to duck out on that prospect? Thus, this incident, which is tragic and important in itself, is also an example of a deeper and much more disturbing aspect in the world. I place that aspect in three categories. The first is that the world is becoming more brutal. People now accept on their television screens the portrayal of bodies, tortured and dead. We hear of instances such as occurred in East Timor where 100,000 to 200,000 people may have died. We are not touched and moved by that to the extent that the world once might have been. That is a signal condemnation of the loss of the power of humanity and a harbinger of a most unpleasant future for the race as a whole. We should speak out whenever this brutality occurs and never condone it under any circumstances.

The second point is that the destructive power of weapons is greater and the aggressor is further from his victim. It is one thing for a Soviet pilot perhaps to have 260-odd people lined up in front of him, be given a sword and be told: ' Here, decapitate these people one after another'. It is another thing for him to sit in the isolation of his cockpit, comforted by the fact that he is being directed by a chain of command somewhere-something which he does not question and something which he allows to overrule his will and his responsibilities as a human being-and to fire a missile which has just the same effect as if he did in fact execute those small children and babies with a sword or an axe. That is something that we have to recognise also when we talk about war and its means.

The third and final point I want to make-I do not think we should prolong this debate unduly-is the paranoid nature that interzonal conflict has adopted. The earnest of that is provided by this particular incident. We are now looking at an interzonal conflict in an area where everything is on a hair trigger, where nerves are stretched taut. People who are using these weapons are prepared at any time for a conflict which might be a nuclear conflict and where even seconds in striking can count. These are the sorts of strains that no human being on the face of the earth should be called upon to carry. We have not matured or developed as a race or as a species to the extent that that is tolerable. If it continues, it can lead only to more incidents of this kind. That is the lesson of this incident and it is a lesson that I will never forget.

The shooting down of this jumbo jet is an object lesson on how easily much worse things could happen, how easily a nuclear conflict could start. If it had not been a misunderstanding about a jumbo jet confused perhaps with a reconnaissance aircraft and fired at with an ordinary heat-seeking missile, if indeed it had been thought, because of some accident, that missiles with atomic warheads were in flight, which is, after all, only a quantitative and not a qualitative difference, the consequences of this incident could have been a conflagration from which the planet might have had very little chance of surviving. A decision was made by a commander with a military mind, trained to have a military mind and trained to react quickly to a situation which was seen as confrontative or possibly dangerous. That confirmed his tendency to respond only in a violent method without any regard for human life. If we do not believe that that could extend to a larger conflict, we are sillier than I think we are. In the event of that larger conflict or threat, the same military mind could well be itching to use his biggest toy, a nuclear weapon.

Some of us here heard that most decorated officer in the United States Army, Colonel David Hackworth-the man who believes this, as I believe it, and on which the film Apocalypse Now was based-say just that. He has been in charge of nuclear weapons in his time and he confirms that indeed only a hair trigger has to be pulled for that larger conflict to start. We need to take a step into the next dimension of last week's tragedy and to consider its implications. The continued stockpiling of nuclear weapons by both sides must make a nuclear conflict more likely and that puts at risk many more lives-an appalling multiplication of the 269 innocent people who died last week.

So, while condemning this atrocity, we believe that Australia should also put all possible pressures on the super-powers to reduce their nuclear stockpiles or at least not to increase them. If they are not increased moneys now spent on nuclear armaments could be spent elsewhere. Half the engineers and half the scientists in the world are now working on producing weapons. If that could be avoided then at least some of the strains of the world could be altered and perhaps, from a purely economic point of view, the likelihood of war could retreat. Of course, the people of the world understand this and they will understand it all the better for what happened last week to the airliner. A million people marched in New York last year over worry and concern about that kind of conflict.

It is much easier to slide downhill than to struggle uphill. It is much easier to do nothing than to try to take some positive action on this sort of thing, to make decisions which may not at first sight be welcome and which may involve some strain or stress or discussion. I think we must do that. We must now carefully question our involvement in the whole zonal and nuclear war machine including our exports of uranium. The view of the Australian Democrats on that matter is well known; I do not have to stress it. We should also, I think, look carefully even at ANZUS and the presence of foreign military bases in this country. We ought to do that for the sake of the people living in this country and for their continued survival.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other senators who have expressed condolences to the relatives of the victims who were killed when the Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 aircraft was shot down by the Soviet fighter aircraft. I also support, and I hope the Government will support, the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). I feel confident that, had the Government been consulted about the amendment prior to its being put down, the Government would, no doubt, have given consideration to it. But this, of course, was out of the hands of the members of parliament. We are now faced with the situation of Parliament meeting and considering a demand for us to take a stand as leaders in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, there is no question that this was a barbaric act deserving condemnation. But the act reflects the barbaric attitude that underlies the Soviet system. One thing that this act tells me is that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is governed by a military dictatorship. There is no question about the fact that in the two hours preceding the shooting down of that plane, information would have been relayed to the Kremlin from the area and that the instructions then given to the fighter pilot were clear and concise 'take fire; fire' with the probable result that the heat-seeking missile struck an inner engine, giving the people on that 747 aircraft something like 12 minutes to consider what had happened to them. It was a deliberate and barbaric act of military dictatorship whose external policies are determined by its military ambitions and whose internal policies are governed by secret police.

I am sorry that Senator Mason took the opportunity to extend this debate. To place this matter in its right context I suggest that if anything proved the need for the absolute necessity of the West to ensure that there is a deterrent, it was the shooting down of the Boeing 747 and the underlying barbaric system that supported that act. It certainly proves that the West must maintain its strength. Finally, I suggest that there are measures which we use as a parliament and, as a people, can adopt. Unfortunately, too many people in the free world give succour to the military dictators in the Kremlin. They do this in a number of ways. They do it by giving some cognisance to the trappings of democracy that these people display. Everyone knows, of course, that the Parliament in the USSR is a greater circus than the Moscow Circus, that trade unions in the USSR are bogus, that they are arms of the state which support the burdens that are placed upon the workers of that country and, indeed, the slave labour workers from outside that country who are working in the Soviet Union. I suggest that one of the actions the Government could take would be to indicate to organisations such as the trade union movement in Australia that they should think carefully about having relationships with bogus trade union organisations in the USSR. It is not so long ago that Alexander Sheletpin was the President of the AUCCTU, which is the trade union movement in the USSR, and came to that position from being head of the KGB.

The Parliament will have the opportunity later this month, in Seoul, as it turns out, at the meeting of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, to make known the feelings of the people of Australia, and the parliaments of the whole world, through the IPU, could make a very vigorous and real protest against the Soviet Union. I believe that these sorts of measures ought to be formulated. I support the Prime Minister and congratulate him for being so forthright in his immediate condemnation of this barbarous act, and I support him in his initiative in making this statement to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Government received somewhat short notice of the Opposition's amendment. I do not complain about that; everything has been at somewhat short notice in relation to this matter. Senator Chaney, as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, informed me that it was not intended that this matter should be pursued to a division. I want to say that, in preparing the statement, the Government regarded it as an appropriate and adequate statement in the circumstances to which the statement refers. In that context we regard the Opposition amendment as not being necessary and as redundant. I want to make it quite clear that the Government is not opposed to the spirit of the Opposition's amendment. I think we have all been in politics long enough to understand it. We are not opposed to the thrust of it. I felt that I should make clear what action the Government would take in that respect.
—The question is that the words proposed to be left out by Senator Chaney's amendment be left out. Those of that opinion say aye, against say no. I think the noes have it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, concerns a book review in relation to which she tabled certain documents in the Senate on 25 August. I ask the Minister whether the text she tabled on 25 August was the exact text she sent for publication.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for her answer. My supplementary question is: When the Minister on 25 August tabled copies of pages 157 and 158 of the book being reviewed, was it to source two quotations, one on each of the pages tabled, which she had included in her text for subsequent publication?
—I have a little difficulty in answering the question quite as precisely as Senator Baume obviously wants me to because I do not have the copies of the extracts.
—The two pages that you tabled each contained a quotation. Were they in the text you put in?

—No. Let me clarify the position. The text which I tabled of a review I wrote of Shirley Williams's book Politics for People is the text as I submitted it to the Sydney Morning Herald. PROCTEXT.PARA: Senate TATE-Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to remarks made by Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association in Launceston last Saturday to the effect that the newly introduced withholding tax is fair and equitable? Did Mr Risstrom, in addressing the annual luncheon of the Launceston Chamber of Commerce, say that many of the building industry organisations such as the Master Builders Association were being dishonest in their representations of the tax? Further, can the Minister indicate whether the Australian Taxation Office is processing applications for exemptions or variations at a satisfactory rate? How many applications have been granted to date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn yesterday to the statement by Mr Risstrom in which he said, among other things, that the withholding tax is fair. As Senator Tate said, some of the complaints that the Master Builders Association and others have raised about the tax are downright dishonest. Mr Risstrom is, of course, right. He might have added that some of the assertions made by members of the Liberal Party, particularly in Western Australia, have been equally dishonest.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the second part of Senator Tate's question I am advised by the Treasurer that at the close of business last Friday-I will use round figures-15, 000 applications for exemption certificates had been received, of which 13,000 had been processed, and more than 38,000 applications for variations of rate had been received, of which nearly 37,000 had been processed. That is a very satisfactory rate of processing the applications which have been received.

As Senator Tate would know, the Government announced a fortnight ago that if the Taxation Office was unable to process applications which had been submitted before the end of August temporary certificates of exemption would automatically be granted. Under some other conditions temporary certificates of exemption would also be granted. In other words, the administration has been handled satisfactorily. To the marginal extent that there are still problems, the Government has altered the original proposal to accommodate those.
