QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESIGNATION OF SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the opinion he gave to the Prime Minister, dated 29 August, concerning the question of the prosecution of Mr Young for a breach of the Crimes Act, which opinion had been requested by the Prime Minister. I refer the Attorney particularly to a paragraph on page 8 of the opinion under the heading 'Need for Deterrence' in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: In the official secrets area, sanctions that have been traditionally regarded as applicable and appropriate to Ministers are not those of the criminal law but the political sanctions of resignation or dismissal. The sanction of resignation has already, of course, applied in the present case.

I ask: Does not this statement by the Attorney-General strongly indicate that the vacancy in Cabinet caused by Mr Young's resignation should be filled without delay? Does the present position mean that in the near future Mr Young may return as a member of the Cabinet Sub-Committee on National and International Security?

TALK.START.PARA: —No implications, one way or the other, of the kind adverted to by the honourable senator either can be or should be read into the particular opinion that I wrote for the Prime Minister and which has been made publicly available. The particular remarks to which Senator Durack referred were made in the very specific context of the proper grounds upon which the discretion to prosecute should be exercised in the event that it ever became clear that a technical offence had been committed. It was in that context, and that context only, that my remarks were written and it is in that context, and that context only, that they should be read.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. In view of the recent attempt, or seeming attempt, by Mr Holmes a Court's Bell group to take over the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, is the Government presently considering altering the National Companies and Securities Commission legislation to prevent this type of activity, which must cause considerable concern to small shareholders and which results in huge profits to companies attempting this type of take-over?

—The matter to which Senator Crowley adverts was discussed, albeit briefly, at the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities in Melbourne last week. It was decided that no action of a legislative remedial kind was in fact appropriate. There is no doubt that Mr Holmes a Court's reported take-over of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is to be construed, as indeed it has been by every financial commentator who has written about it, as not so much a take-over attempt properly so called as rather one that should be regarded as a sophisticated attempt in capital raising and in changing the capital base of the Western Australian company in question. As I understand it and as the Ministerial Council understands it, BHP has agreed to treat the matter as a take-over bid in the ordinary way and has not sought from the National Companies and Securities Commission exemption from the obligations imposed upon it by the present take-over code. In the event that circumstances of this kind were to recur in the future and it became clear that oppressive obligations were being placed upon recipients of take-over bids in circumstances where there might be reasonable doubt as to whether a bona fide take-over was in fact being contemplated, there is no doubt I believe, in the light of last week' s discussions, that serious attention would be given by the National Companies and Securities Commission to the exercise of its discretion to exempt such target companies from the very substantial, wide-ranging and expensive obligations that the present legislative code places upon them. But in the absence of such a claim being made by BHP in this case, it does appear that Mr Holmes a Court has found his way yet again through the legislation in a very sophisticated fashion and it remains to be seen how the market responds to his particular adventure.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is the Minister aware of the large advertisements placed in major newspapers recently by the Roxby Downs joint venturers claiming, among other things, that nuclear energy is reponsible for no deaths or injuries from radiation and that no nuclear reactor has ever provided material for nuclear weapons? Is the Minister aware that these two claims are demonstrably false and quite clearly are lies? Is the Minister aware that, according to the United States Academy of Sciences, the United States nuclear power industry will have been responsible for 2,000 cancer deaths by the year 2000 and that even in Australia a man died from leukemia after radiation exposure from the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights in April 1977? Is the Minister aware that Britain, India and possibly many other countries have used civilian nuclear power reactors as sources of materials for nuclear weapons? Given these facts, will the Government act on what appears to be a breach of the Trade Practices Act, sections 52, 55 and 55A, which is designed to ensure that a company does not engage in misleading or deceptive conduct? If breaches are established, will the Government prosecute the joint venturers?

—I am sure that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, like all other Ministers in the Government and all other members and supporters of the Government, is aware of the great dangers associated with the use of nuclear weapons and, indeed, with the role that the acceleration of the nuclear fuel cycle plays in creating hazards of various kinds, including health hazards. It is because the Australian Labor Party is aware of the kinds of hazards to which Senator Chipp's question adverts that it has resolved the anti-uranium policy which is the policy of this Government. However, with regard to the specific matters that Senator Chipp brings before the Senate today relating to the advertisements concerning Roxby Downs, I have notified the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment of Senator Chipp's claims about the misleading nature of those advertisements. I will refer the advertisements and Senator Chipp's question to the Minister. I am sure that if, in his judgment, it is proper to investigate alleged breaches of sections 52, 55 and 55A of the Trade Practices Act, then he will do so and report the results to Senator Chipp.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. What reasoning lay behind the Federal Budget decision to give approval for Esso-BHP to export crude oil from the Fortescue field in Bass Strait? Does the Government see any disadvantages in allowing the export of that oil, possibly up to 27,000 barrels a day, considering that new oil gives the Government no levy revenue? In view of the fact that Australia is currently 66 per cent self-sufficient in crude oil but that failing new discoveries this figure is expected to fall to 22 per cent by the year 2000, what priority is the Government placing on the conservation and responsible use of non-renewable fossil fuel supplies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray has asked a number of questions. Early in its life, shortly after being elected, the Government received estimates from the producers of the likely production in the current financial year of oil from the Fortescue field which, as Senator Ray mentioned, is classified as new oil and is exempt from excise. Subsequently, estimates were received of very much higher levels of production from Fortescue which had indirect implications for government revenue because it appeared at the time that local refiners would not take up all the crude oil which was being produced. In a situation of production capacity surplus to Australia's current refinery uptake, it was quite clear that given the choice between producing excise-free Fortescue oil and shutting down excise payable old oil, the producers would be likely to shut in old oil and to do so to a greater degree in view of the then forecast higher production levels from Fortescue. However, since then it appears that the uplift situation-that is , the lifting of Australian crude by domestic refiners-will be better than it was at that stage. For a number of reasons the likely production from Fortescue will be somewhat lower than was anticipated a couple of months ago.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, not wishing to penalise the producers in regard to the production of Fortescue oil, made a decision that a maximum of 18 million barrels of excise-free oil from Fortescue could be absorbed on the domestic market, but if the producers were capable of producing more than that they could export it on a spot basis. Incidentally, oil from other fields can be exported on a spot basis if such oil is produced surplus to Australian requirements. It is correct, as Senator Ray said, that no excise revenue will be received on Fortescue production which may be exported. Substantial royalties of the order of $40m, however, are likely to be received this year by the State of Victoria from Fortescue. In the following year corporate taxation will be received by the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you will make it clear that that dorothy dixer is from your colleague and not me. It was asked by Senator Robert Ray.

—This is an important matter, and I think it is as well to put it on the record. No representations have been received-by me, anyway-objecting to the decision to allow Australian crude to be exported. I had thought that some people might criticise the decision to export a finite resource. There is, however, no conceptual difference between moving to maximise the absorption of Australian crude as distinct from importing additional crude and exporting Australian crude. That was the way the Government saw it. With respect to research into alternative forms of energy, over a number of years some $26m has been spent on solar research. However, the Government's current belief is that with present technology the potential for solar energy to displace other forms of energy is quite limited-probably a maximum of around 3 per cent of total energy input. Funds have been provided for research into biomass and the production of ethanol and so on, but at present prices these fuels are not competitive with crude oil.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Budget allocation of $25,000 for the Disabled Persons International organisation. Is it a fact that in addressing a DPI conference in January the Minister stated that he was prepared to commit any government he was involved with to a realistic level of funding for DPI and that in a telegram during the election campaign the present Prime Minister promised DPI a direct and untied grant of $50,000? Is the Minister aware that prior to the presentation of the Budget members of DPI were advised by his office that DPI would receive that $50 ,000 in the Budget? How does the Minister reconcile his and the Prime Minister's earlier commitments and the actual Budget allocation of half the expected amount ? What assistance can the Minister provide to enable DPI to establish an office and employ a secretary so that it can continue its work on behalf of its membership?

—The answer to the penultimate part of Senator Messner's question is no, it is not true that someone from my office informed DPI that it would get $50,000 in this Budget. I certainly would not have authorised any such statement to be made. Secondly, I point out that this allocation of $25,000 to DPI is not the first allocation by this Government to DPI-in fact, the Government assisted Disabled Persons International at an earlier date in conducting meetings and in establishing branches in different States-nor will it necesssarily be the last allocation of funds to Disabled Persons International. Disabled Persons International is an organisation which I will continue to support. A number of members of the Disabled Persons International executive are in fact on the Disability Advisory Council established by me on behalf of this Government. Since the Budget I have discussed with at least one executive member of Disabled Persons International the reason that its Budget allocation was $25,000 and not $50,000. We were uncertain of how far DPI had got in establishing its national organisation and I told that organisation, both before and after the Budget, that we would consider a further allocation of funds should that be necessary. The organisation knows that that will happen should it need more money. Disabled Persons International is an important organisation. It is an organisation made up of disabled persons only which at last gives disabled persons a majority say- in fact, a complete say in this case-in an organisation involving their own affairs. They deserve the support of this Parliament; they deserve the support of this Government. We are the first government to allocate funds to this organisation and we will continue to support it in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister seen reports to the effect that the Government's proposed assets test represents a cowardly attack on pensioners? I ask the Minister whether he can say which groups of pensioners will be affected and whether he can comment on how it will affect pensioners who put capital into investments such as those promoted by the Australian Fixed Trusts group, which has advertised as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: Getting the pension and being eligible for its fringe benefits should be the aim of your investment strategies as you near retirement, no matter how wealthy you are.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have seen reports that the Government's proposed assets test represents a cowardly attack on pensioners. That was said by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock. It is an interesting comment by Mr Peacock, considering the fact that on at least three occasions in the last year he has advocated the reintroduction of a means test for pensioners, which in fact is the application of an assets test on top of the income test. Mr Peacock's consistency in this matter is well known. To answer the last part of Senator Maguire's question, I must say that over the years I and members on both sides of the chamber have deplored the activities of various organisations, including Australian Fixed Trusts, in what one might describe as working the pensioners in order to overcome the income test. It is no secret that the previous Government was making efforts to overcome the very real problem of people circumventing the income test. As Senator Maguire said, organisations which do this make no bones about what they are doing. Australian Fixed Trusts, in its advertising, states:

ANSWER.PARA: It is possible for even a millionaire to get the pension and fringe benefits on retirement. Getting the pension and being eligible for its fringe benefits should be the aim of your investment strategies as you near retirement, no matter how wealthy you are.

The people taking advantage of this situation are doing so at the expense of those on fixed superannuation payments and other fixed incomes, and they are taking advantage of those pensioners on the base rate of pension, because governments of whatever persuasion are unable to raise the base rate of pension to a sufficient level. In fact, these people are taking advantage of the taxpayers. It is for this reason that we, like many other people in the community, have advocated and will introduce an assets test. As for the number of people who will be affected, of the two million pensioners in this country it is estimated that one and a half million will not be affected at all, another 170,000 will be better off and many of the 340,000 who are affected will be affected only marginally. I remind honourable senators that the upper level of assets and income-on top of all the areas which will be exempt-at which a pensioner will first lose his or her pension will be $104,000 for a single pensioner and $170,000 for married pensioners. I suggest that the introduction of such an assets test is neither mean-minded nor does it represent a cowardly attack on pensioners. The majority of pensioner organisations I have seen in the last week in fact agree with the introduction of an assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is it correct that, although the Government undertook to maintain funding to local government in constant terms, with Australia's inflation running at 11.2 per cent and local government reimbursements at 8.2 per cent our councils are losing heavily on the deal, to the tune of 3 per cent per annum? Does the Minister recognise the unemployment and loss of capital works that this real loss in councils' income will create? Is it the intention of the Government to save this 3 per cent so that it can be paid to those who will now join the rapidly growing ranks of the unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer to Senator Archer's question is no, it is not correct that there has been a reduction in real terms in funding to local government. It does not surprise me that Senator Archer is incapable of understanding why that claim is not correct. The reason it is not correct is that the 11.2 per cent figure, which he claimed as the rate of inflation prevailing-if I remember correctly-was for June 1983 on June 1982. From memory, I believe the anticipated rate of inflation throughout the financial year 1983- 84 over the financial year 1982-83 is 7.5 per cent. Local government funds have been increased by 8.2 per cent. So when the situation is properly assessed--
—You tell local government that.

—Senator Walters would have no chance of comprehending this, even after it has been explained. In real terms, properly assessed, there has been an increase in the local government tax sharing funds. Moreover, there has been a massive increase in all payments to local government of the order of $300m. I have quoted that figure from memory. I will check it with the Treasurer and, if it is substantially at variance with the official record, I will notify the Senate later. There has been an increase, in money terms, of the order of 50 per cent in payments to local government from all sources.

ANSWER.PARA: I might add that as Commonwealth funding to local governments has been increased progressively over recent years, State funds have been withdrawn progressively. Most notably this has happened in Queensland, but to a lesser extent there has been a tendency in other States to reduce the amount of State government funds going to local government as Commonwealth payments have been increased. It is certainly to be hoped that State governments desist from doing that this year because of the very large increase in total Commonwealth payments to local government. Particularly, it is to be hoped that the Queensland Government, which has been the worst offender in this respect, desists from doing that for the very good reason which Senator Archer stated; that is, that anything which reduces the real level of funding to local government will have serious employment implications and will create significant increases in unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Are we to assume that that is an undertaking that, in the event of inflation being higher than 7.5 per cent, the balance that has been taken from above that to the current rate of inflation will be restored at the end of the financial year?

—There has never been any such undertaking. The best available estimates indicate that the consumer price index increase will be 7.5 per cent. It is on that basis, that expectation, that there is an increase in real terms, properly assessed, on what economists call a year-on-year basis, in payments to local government from tax sharing. I mentioned before the very much larger increase in real terms in payments to local government from other sources.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In view of the excellent support services given to Australians living in remote areas by the Bush Nurses Association, can the Minister give an undertaking to have investigated the anomaly which presently prevents the Bush Nurses Association from receiving Federal Government financial assistance on the same basis as that given to the Blue Nursing Service in urban areas?

—Yes, I will give an undertaking to Senator Reynolds that I will determine from the Minister for Health what can be done about the situation, if it exists. I am sure it does, as Senator Reynolds has said. I am aware of the good work that the Bush Nurses Association does and I would certainly not like to see it in a disadvantageous situation because of some anomaly in the regulations or the legislation in this Parliament.

—I refer the Minister for Education to the latest Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission guidelines, particularly to the section on disadvantaged groups. Why is no definition given as to who is a member of a disadvantaged group?
—You would not know; that is for sure.

—I do not have the background that the honourable senator has. Why, in the face of this lack of definition, have the universities and colleges of advanced education been given a quota of disadvantaged students to enrol in 1984? Is the Minister aware that these quotas will be filled, in the most part, by the administrations of the various universities and CAEs lowering their entrance standards, thereby defeating the purpose behind helping disadvantaged groups which, since they are not defined, cannot be identified anyway? Is it not wrong to enrol a student who has demonstrated that he or she does not have the intellectual and other abilities to meet the normal entrance standards? Finally, is it not doing a grave injustice to those students who lie just beyond the entrance standards and who want to go to a university or some tertiary education institution but who cannot lay claim to some undefined disadvantaged status?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the most straightforward answer to Senator MacGibbon's question as to who are disadvantaged people with regard to access to universities is that they are those who are not there. On looking at the socio- economic composition of universities and other institutions of higher education it will be found that they still contain quite a narrow group of people. In other words, it is still the case that if one comes from an affluent family, if one is not Aboriginal or not from a migrant group, one is much more likely to go to institutions of higher education than if one is from a poor family, is a migrant or an Aboriginal. Although the participation of women in higher education has been increasing numerically, since the Whitlam Government abolished fees for tertiary education in 1974, it is still the case that in certain faculties of universities, such as engineering, architecture and some areas of science, women are seriously under-represented. So the answer to Senator MacGibbon's question is that we regard those groups who have previously not had access to higher education in this country as being disadvantaged in that respect.

QUESTION.PARA: However, I should make it clear that the matter of deciding who shall be admitted to universities or CAEs is fundamentally a matter for those institutions. The Commonwealth Government is not going to take unto itself the selection of students. Nonetheless, we have said in our guidelines that we expect universities and CAEs to make special efforts to ensure that previously disadvantaged groups have more access than they have had. We have provided an extra $10m to be made available via the Tertiary Education Commission to those institutions which demonstrate that they are able to be more accessible to disadvantaged groups than has previously been the case. It will be up to those institutions to determine whether they can take more Aboriginals, whether they can take women into engineering courses or whatever.

With regard to the other matter raised by Senator MacGibbon, I disagree with him entirely that there is something wrong in saying that people who do not meet normal entrance requirements should be admitted to university. For example, we believe that Aboriginals have been excluded not only from access to higher education but also, in effect, from completing their secondary schooling. This has happened for a number of reasons which have been the subject of many debates in this chamber and which I will not go over now. But it has also been the experience of those universities which have made a special effort to encourage the enrolment of Aboriginals and to provide special support for them-for example , through the Enclave program which the James Cook University in Townsville is operating for Aboriginal teacher trainees-that they have had a high degree of success.

We now have a situation where there are some-still very few-tertiary qualified Aboriginals. For example, there is a plan by the University of Newcastle to seek a small number of applicants for its school of medicine. At this stage-Senator MacGibbon may not be aware of it-there is not one medically qualified Aboriginal in Australia. This Government does not believe that that demonstrates that Aboriginals are not intelligent enough to do medicine. It demonstrates that a whole history of disadvantage, manifested in all sorts of ways, has made it very difficult-overwhelmingly difficult to this point-for an Aboriginal person to undertake medical studies and graduate as a doctor. But the University of Newcastle has decided to take positive steps to work with Aboriginal groups in identifying suitable students and providing appropriate bridging courses and assistance. I wish the university well in this task and believe that in a few years time as a result of its efforts we will see the first Aboriginal medical graduate. Perhaps that example demonstrates to Senator MacGibbon what this Government means when it states in its guidelines for tertiary institutions that it expects universities and other institutions of higher education to take active steps to become more accessible. We certainly do not expect that there will be any lowering of standards as a result. We believe that standards of education in the community generally will be raised and in particular there will be a raising of educational and professional standards amongst those groups which previously have been disadvantaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry that the Minister did not listen carefully or devote her few resources to my question. I come back to the central point: What is the definition of a disadvantaged person? Is it simply one who is poor, a migrant or an Aboriginal?
—I repeat the answer that I gave to Senator MacGibbon's original question.
—Senator Sibraa told you that-a Queensland Liberal.

—I will not adopt the suggestion of my colleague Senator Walsh that Queensland Liberals are disadvantaged persons because I believe some of them have had access to tertiary education, although it does not always show. In the context of access to tertiary education, disadvantaged people or groups are those who, because of various educational and selection practices, perhaps because of the funding restrictions imposed by the previous Government, do not currently appear in the population of institutions of higher learning.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. TALK.START.PARA: —The problems of handicapped persons undertaking tertiary studies and doing sufficient hours per week to qualify them for the TEAS allowance have been brought to my attention by Senator Colston and by other members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives. The problem is that many handicapped people are intellectually well able to undertake tertiary studies but, because of their handicap, do not have the stamina to undertake a full study load. At the moment the TEAS regulations, under which I have no ministerial discretion, lay down a certain number of hours that must be pursued before a student can be eligible for the allowance. Of course, there are handicapped people who cannot undertake that load but who still need TEAS and who still wish to pursue their tertiary studies. —Is the Attorney-General able to inform the Senate whether there has been any change of approach by the Government in relation to the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill? Will the debate on any clauses or amendments be conducted on a free vote basis so far as the Government is concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having now had the experience of several hours of debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill, and facing the prospect of several more hours of debate, I recommended to the Government party today that, in fact, a free vote be allowed so far as the Government is concerned on a number of clauses which can be characterised in one way or the other as involving traditional moral issues such as the evaluation of the conduct of parties to a marriage and measures also said to be designed to preserve the institution of marriage. Out of the almost numberless amendments that have been moved, or clauses that are still to be considered in this debate, there would appear to be eight particular matters which satisfy that description. I will list them briefly for the convenience of the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: First, there is clause 47 of the Bill, which is the so-called divorce by post clause. Then there are four amendments proposed to be moved by Senator Harradine : His proposed new clause 4BA relating to compulsory reconciliation counselling in all applications for dissolution; his proposed amendment to clause 20 relating to proceedings in relation to the dissolution of marriages of less than three years duration not being instituted without the leave of the court; his proposed amendment to clause 20 relating to the introduction of fault grounds for divorce in addition to the two-year separation period; and a further amendment of his to clause 20, also on the question of the irretrievable breakdown period being extended to two years. So far as Senator Walters's amendments are concerned, there are three which it is proposed should be treated on a free vote basis: Her amendment to clause 25, taking into account the conduct of parents in custody matters; a further amendment to clause 30 relating to the conduct of parents in maintenance and property matters; and, finally, a particular amendment that is proposed by Senator Walters in relation to clause 47 concerning divorce by post.

I make it clear that this is not as a result of any representations made to me by any member of the Government party claiming to have been stood over or in any other way to have been disadvantaged in presenting a point of view. It is simply a response to the course of debate in this place, and the view expressed in particular by a number of senior members of the other parties that it would expedite the course of the debate were there to be a free vote on these particular matters. It is on that basis that the Government has changed its position and will approach the debate accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which relates to the assets test for pensioners, is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: Is it true that, as well as a place of residence, furniture, jewellery, works of art and so on, a caravan and a boat are to be included as non-assessable items? If those things are both true, will the Minister have the Government re-examine this whole matter of which things are to be included and which are not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Government announced its intention of introducing an assets test, it listed the sorts of things which it believed should be exempt from the assets test, largely based on the previous assets test as it existed. It also announced in that same announcement that it would in fact be consulting with various pensioner organisations and other interested groups. That is in fact what I have been doing. In the time that Senator Gietzelt and I have been talking to various groups, the matter of the holiday home, the beach house or the bush shack has come up and the two of us have agreed that we will take this into consideration when the Government eventually draws up the guidelines and the legislation. One would imagine that, if we were willing to exempt assets such as those, we would have to look at putting a limit on them. Whether we put a limit on assets, as some pensioner organisations have suggested, by saying that people can have a car and a caravan or a holiday house or whether we put a limit on the value of the holiday house or whether we put a limit on the value of a residence and a holiday house is a matter for discussion and I have discussed these matters with various organisations.

ANSWER.PARA: I emphasise that what we did was put down a statement of intent. We announced that we would be spending a couple of months negotiating with various pensioner organisations and others and that the legislation would then come in and that it would take about a year to be in place. In that time we will continue, as we have done, to consult with various groups. I think this is a sensible way to go about it. I am sorry that one group at least appears not to be willing to consult but has made up its mind from the word go. However, I believe that once we have had discussions and consultations with that group we can come to a satisfactory agreement in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which refers to the present Government's commitment to identifying and effectively assisting those most needy in our community, is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Will the Minister advise whether consideration has been given to moving away from the inequitable submission approach for funding of welfare agencies? Does the Government intend setting up a planning model for the States to investigate the greatest areas of need for funding?

—Yes, as Senator Elstob has said, our policy is to have a welfare system based on assistance to those in need, not only in the income support area but also in the area of welfare services. In the past, in some areas-one can particularly single out perhaps the area of children's services and in some States the area of aged persons accommodation-there has been a maldistribution of funds assistance because the method used to distribute those funds has been one based on a submission model and of necessity those communities with most social cohesion, those communities with most education, those best able to handle the submission and bureaucratic processes have tended to do best. We intend in both of those areas to move to a planning model where we will redirect funds more to those in need than to those with the capacity to make submissions. That does not mean that people will not be able to make submissions. It does not mean that we will not take any notice of submissions. Submissions will still be coming from areas of need and all submissions will be treated responsibly. But there will be, as there are now, some areas from which, because of the nature of the areas and because of the socio-economic position of the people in those areas, submissions may not come at all. In that circumstance we are in consultation with the States and various organisations looking now at methods of overcoming the inequities inherent in a purely submission type of system.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It concerns the effect of the new superannuation tax on members of the Defence Force. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that less than one per cent of those who join the Defence Force and are thereby compulsorily enrolled in a superannuation scheme can expect to reach the age of 55 years without being earlier compulsorily retired from the Defence Force? —I understand that discussions are presently proceeding between the Minister for Defence and the Treasurer on most, if not all, of the matters to which Senator Hamer has referred. The most I can do at this stage is to refer the question to the Minister for Defence for a detailed reply which I hope will be forthcoming shortly.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that the superannuation lump sum tax may be varied again?

—I am simply saying that, because of the noise being made by the honourable senator and all sorts of other people, it may be that there is a case for the further consideration of this matter, as any sensible government would acknowledge. Such discussions are proceeding.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer him to reports that South Australia has now joined with Victoria in its contention that truth alone should be a complete defence to defamation actions. Can the Minister say whether this is so and whether such a move is a change from the consensus reached by Attorneys-General in July this year? Is it a fact that at present truth is an absolute defence to defamation suits in Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory? Is it also a fact that, by their adoption of a public benefits concept in uniform legislation, Attorneys-General have adopted a concept which in some States would lead to a more restrictive attitude on truthful reporting and publication? In view of this reported change from South Australia, will the Federal Government now revise its position on this matter to ensure that truth can serve as an adequate and absolute defence in defamation suits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was the subject of discussion at the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General last week. At that meeting I indicated that the position of the Commonwealth Government, the Australian Labor Party in government, had always been one of support for the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission; that our position was that truth and truth alone should be an appropriate defence, at least in the context of justification , so far as defamation proceedings were concerned, but that there should also be protection for individuals so far as unjustified invasions of privacy were concerned. In brief, the history of the matter is that over a long period a majority of Ministers at the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General have been in favour of not dealing with privacy as part of the exercise in the law of defamation but postponing that to another day, and in the context of the proper treatment of the defence of justification have been in favour of casting that defence so that truth alone would not be good enough, that public benefit would be needed as well. That has simply been a majority position among Ministers. Certainly the Commonwealth Government, like the South Australian and Victorian governments, has expressed considerable reservations about the appropriateness of that approach to the defence of justification.

ANSWER.PARA: I have indicated to the Standing Committee that at the time the proposed exposure draft of a Bill on defamation is released-we still hope that that will be in the latter part of this year-I will also put down for public consideration an alternative approach to the drafting of the defence of justification, one that is based on truth alone but which at the same time has regard to sensitive private facts and allows aggrieved individuals another course of redress when things have been published about them which are true but which constitute an unjustifiable invasion of privacy. The Government has yet, as a government, to reach a final and formal position on these matters, but I make it clear, in response to all the battering that I, rather unjustifiably, have been getting recently on this issue in the media, that it is still very much a live issue and is not to be regarded as foreclosed.

I wish to speak briefly to the Australian Wheat Board's annual report 1981-82. In doing so, I refer to the sixth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, entitled 'Statutory Authorities of the Commonwealth'. In chapter 3 of that report reference is made to the now long- standing saga of the reports of the Australian Wheat Board. This comment was made in paragraph 3.2.5 of the report:
Future annual reports of the Board will be scrutinised for continuing progress in these matters.

I have no doubt that the history of the reports is reasonably well known. The position now is that a report has been tabled reasonably within time, bearing in mind the year the report covers. It is relatively unqualified, bearing in mind the nature of qualifications which in previous years have been received by the Wheat Board. On this occasion financial statements, which there had been some difficulty in preparing in previous years, have been included. The qualifications are set out in paragraph (c) of the Auditor-General's report, which states:
(c) the receipt, expenditure and investment of moneys, and the acquisition and disposal of assets, by the Board during the period have been in accordance with the Act except that:

payments associated with the premium element of sales revenue were not included in advance payments to growers under section 21 and did not form part of the net pool return determined under section 9,
certain quantities of wheat received during the 1981-82 season were designated as 1982-83 season receivals (Note 1 (e) to the financial statements refers), and
advance payments to growers in respect of some wheat delivered during the 1980- 81 season were made on account of final payments for the 1981-82 season.

If there had been qualifications similar to that for an ordinary statutory authority reporting and receiving that sort of qualification by the Auditor- General it would be grounds for an expression of some concern that less than unqualified financial statements had been obtained and that the procedures were obviously defective and in need of some improvement.

The report indicates that the Wheat Board has substantially overcome the multitude of problems which have existed for many years and which have been the subject matter of adverse comment by the Senate as a whole and by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in particular. I am pleased to see that the day has arrived when the Australian Wheat Board is able to present to this chamber, to the people of Australia and, in particular, to the wheat growers of Australia a report which does not cause great concern and which is getting close to being what I think is the objective of those who manage the Wheat Board and certainly the objective of the Senate-that is, an unqualified report, one which shows that the system is working efficiently and effectively and that the accounting problems have been totally overcome.

I point to the fact that there are still in existence very considerable problems around Australia in relation to the marketing of grain. Recent events relating to the Queensland Graingrowers Association, the Grain Sorghum Marketing Board for the State of New South Wales, the Grain Pool of Western Australia and a number of others indicate that further steps are still necessary. I hope that this Government and, in particular, those with a direct responsibility for the operation of wheat marketing and grain marketing systems in Australia, will continue the work which was undertaken last year and earlier to try to improve the system of handling of all wheat and the sale of all grain in Australia and to ensure an effective inter relationship between the various bodies. Without taking undue time, I simply compliment the Wheat Board on having achieved as much as it has. I compliment the Auditor-General on the patience which as been displayed by his staff in relation to this matter. I hope that next year there will be totally unqualified Auditor-General's report on the Australian Wheat Board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I indicate my pleasure at finding that the report of the Australian Wheat Board is based on very excellent accounts and records. The report highlights the importance of the Wheat Board in the world in which we trade to the Australian farming community directly and to the vast number of other people who are in no small measure dependent upon it. The Australian Wheat Board has taken advantage of amendments to the 1979 Wheat Marketing Act which allow a greater measure of commercial flexibility than had been the case. One is continually reminded of the important role that the Wheat Board plays as the trading representative of many thousands of people in agricultural Australia. There is a tendency today for world trade to be dominated by massive blocs of countries or governments. In that circumstance probably the only real chance of survival for the individual in such an individualist industry is to be represented at an international level by a body that can talk to the trading blocs and governments around the world. That, is the great contribution that the Australian Wheat Board makes. The amendments to the legislation to which I referred included such things as the right to trade on futures markets. This, and a number of other relatively minor amendments, have given a real measure of flexibility to the Wheat Board.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Wheat Board at present finds itself in considerable difficulty in a trading world in which attitudes in America are changing and subsidised European grain is being placed on world markets. As a result, the Board is confronted by very difficult circumstances. We have to look at and take cognisance of this problem. Australian wheat is recognised as equal to the best, if not the best, in the world. Yet, the Wheat Board is confronted by an extraordinary level of subsidy and an unreal price situation in the international market. It is pleasing to note that the report of the Australian Wheat Board is acceptable to the Auditor-General. The report draws attention to the problems that relate to wheat trading and signifies the necesity for the Board to carry out its obligations.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY SMOKING AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS ADVERTISEMENTS PROHIBITION BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Jack Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit advertisements relating to smoking and tobacco products in the Australian Capital Territory and for related purposes.
Bill presented by Senator Jack Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to prohibit advertisements relating to smoking and to tobacco products in the Australian Capital Territory. I propose this Bill as the Australian Democrats spokesperson for sport and recreation. I do so in an effort to protect the children of Australia and to prevent debasement of sport and recreation. After many years of active involvement with sporting organisations I am appalled at the way tobacco companies use sport as a means of enticing young Australians into tobacco addiction. This Bill is intended to protect young Australians from the influences which encourage them to begin smoking tobacco. It is a tragedy that young Australians are being subjected to such pressures. It is even worse when activities such as sport and recreation are abused by using them as vehicles for luring young Australians into addiction . The Government currently spends millions of dollars on curative medicine relating to diseases and ailments associated with the use of tobacco products. Preventive action can ease the cost and burden which society has to bear resulting from the use of tobacco products. This Bill is a small step towards lifting that burden.

A small portion of the money saved as a result of prevention, rather than cure, will need to be invested in the sporting organisations. This investment will be for two purposes. Firstly, the abolition of tobacco advertising will have an effect on the economy of some sporting organsiations. It is therefore appropriate that the Government should compensate sports organisations for their loss in revenue. Such compensation would be insignificant compared with the potential savings gained from reduced health expenditure. Secondly, as acknowledged by the Government in its election platform, sport and recreation has a major role to play in preventive health. It is important therefore that the Government allocate appropriate levels of funds to ensure that sport continues to play an ever increasing role in the community and in the preventive health area.

The question is frequently asked whether there is a proven link between tobacco advertising and the enticement of children into smoking. The linkage is indisputable. At the same time as adult rates of smoking are diminishing, there is a dramatic increase in Australia in the rate of children, and particularly young children, commencing to smoke tobacco. The tobacco product has been proven to be habit forming and indeed, to most young people, becomes addictive in their late teens. The tragedy is that at the very time when sports leaders are doing their best to attract and retain teenage youngsters in sport for the good of their health, the tobacco product is sealing the fate of these young people by destroying their lungs and their general health, making them less capable of participating at their full potential in sporting activities.

This Bill reflects the wishes of the majority of Australians. In August 1981 a McNair Anderson survey throughout Australia asked the following question, ' Should televised sporting events which can be seen by children, be used to promote cigarettes'. The response was a decisive 79 per cent of respondents answering, no. It is now up to this Parliament to accept its responsibility to protect young Australians from becoming addicted to tobacco products. As with the introduction of seat belt legislation, the Parliament should encourage the protection of health and of human life. It must also acknowledge the burdens and costs which society must bear because of children being lured into the use of tobacco.

Several States within Australia have realised the value of protecting our furture generations and are currently contemplating legislation similar to this Bill. This Bill will thus act in conjunction with State legislation to ensure that all young Australians are protected from the advertising which could tempt them into tobacco addiction. This Bill must pass for the sake of Australia's children and the future health of the people of this country.
