SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare: Existing retirement income systems, with particular reference to any changes which may be necessary to ensure equitable and comprehensive income security for Australians of retirement age.
(2) That the Committee report to the Senate on or before the first sitting day in August 1984.

Eighteen months ago the present Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) took the former Government to task for announcing measures affecting pensioners before they had been fully thought out. As a result, in various places he declared:
. . . there has been continual speculation amongst pensioners and other retired people in the community as to just where they stood.
Senator Grimes, at that stage, went on to say:
There has been considerable anxiety and uncertainty among people who arranged their affairs under the old rules as to just what is happening.

Looking back at those remarks of Senator Grimes in March 1982 one is almost forced to believe that he had an insight into the future. Over the last six months, during the life of this Hawke Labor Government, there has been continual speculation amongst pensioners, other retired people and people approaching retirement as to just where they stood under this Government. These groups understandably are anxious and concerned about how their plans, which were made under the old rules and arrangements, will stand up under the Hawke Government, which is continually making changes to that system without adopting a comprehensive approach.

Since its election 27 weeks ago the Government has made three major announcements in the field of retirement income policy. We have seen changes to the taxation arrangements relating to lump sum superannuation payments, the introduction of an income test for pensioners over 70 years of age and, as announced in the Budget a fortnight ago, the introduction late next year of the Labor Government's assets test. All these announcements have caused a great deal of confusion. I believe that it has resulted from a failure of the Government to adopt a total, overall and comprehensive approach in this area. The Government's announcements have all the hallmarks of decisions made hastily in a mere effort to raise revenue. Indeed, given that the superannuation changes and the income test are superseded by the assets test, the policy formulation in this most important area could almost reflect Senator Gareth Evans's ethos in doing things ; that is, it seemed like a good idea at the time.

Let there be no mistake. The three major announcements made by the Government in this area cannot be seen as part of any consistent or coherent policy. The three announcements are not part of an overall plan. They are in fact unrelated and even mutually exclusive. If this assets test had been the intention of the Government all along, as I stated publicly before the Budget was presented, why did the Government act to deter people from taking lump sum payments so that, according to its argument, they could not 'double dip'? The introduction of Labor's assets test overrides the purpose of those changes. If that test had been the intention all along, why did the Government announce in the mini-Budget that an income test for pensioners over 70 would be imposed from 1 November this year? The introduction of Labor's assets test overrides the income test and means that the whole exercise associated with the introduction of that test was a waste of time and effort and caused undue concern to the most senior section of the community. Where is the consistency in these changes? Where is the evidence of a broad approach? There is none and there will not be until we have an inquiry into the adequacy of retirement income systems generally, with particular emphasis on the need for both an equitable and comprehensive approach . The Government shows no willingness to undertake such a course of action. That is the reason I have proposed this motion today.

I wish to take some of the Senate's time to discuss specific items which will provide an understanding of the Opposition's purpose in trying to point out some of the anomalies which exist. First, I look at the question of lump sum superannuation payments. As we all know, despite public commitments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the National Economic Summit Conference in April, the taxation arrangements relating to lump sum superannuation payments were altered in the mini-Budget. To be correct, they were also further changed and clarified on 31 May and 10 August 1983 by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as a result of discussion and pressure from the unions and sections of industry.

There is no need for me to run through those original changes but I remind the Senate of the anomalies and issues which arose after they were announced and caused considerable concern and confusion. Firstly, it took weeks before an announcement was made to clear up the concern that the changes amounted to a de facto death tax which would apply to moneys received by the beneficiaries and dependants of members of funds who had died.

Secondly, the original changes discriminated-and the latest changes do not alter this-against Defence Force personnel who are subject to compulsory retirement due to age and rank factors. A range of industries is also touched in that way. Thirdly, they discriminated against the self-employed, who cannot take advantage of the benefits of tax-free employer contributions. Even after the most recent changes this group is discriminated against. It is doubtful that the Government's approved deposit funds will be beneficial to those self-employed people. Fourthly, the changes to be made to the Life Insurance Act, which will determine the rights of return of annuities, are still to be announced. Fifthly, the definition of 'contractual termination payment' and 'bona fide redundancy payment' are still to be clarrified and made public to the people generally.

These and other issues were the subject of examination by the joint Australian Council of Trade Unions and Confederation of Australian Industry task force, the report of which should be made public. Hopefully many of these issues may be resolved in that report. Members of the Opposition still have not seen the report, although we called for its tabling during the last sittings of Parliament. We would also like to know what other reports have been commissioned by the Government in the social welfare area, and we seek their tabling. Will the Government be able in various ways to offer people who receive lump sums and roll them over into annuities the assurance that the income they receive will be indexed to take account of inflation? If the Government cannot guarantee that, surely the changes will act as a disincentive for people to join superannuation schemes and people will look to the age pension as the sole source of retirement income.

I believe the point to be made from that fact is that this can lead only to higher levels of social security expenditure when, as a major part of the justification for the change, the Government was looking to save money through the elimination of double dipping. If the Government had always intended to introduce this assets test there would have been no need to make lump sums so unattractive-they would have been picked up in the kind of assets test which the Minister has outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless you buy jewellery.

—Unless you buy jewellery or works of art, as Senator Chaney points out. I turn to the income test which is now to apply to persons over 70 years of age. In the May mini-Budget the Government announced its decision, with effect from 1 November, to introduce that test. Again the Government acted to overcome what it saw as the problem that had bedevilled the provision of decent support for the aged; namely, the way in which resources had been sprayed around indiscriminately. But if Labor's assets test was the Government's grand plan in regard to the whole area of retirement income the exercise was a total waste of time, the many distressed pensioners who contacted my office-and I am sure they contacted others-in the last few days need not have worried about what the Government would do with their pensions. As it is, these people now have two things to worry about; namely, whether they will still have a pension after 1 November 1983 as a result of the introduction of the income test and whether they will still have a pension after the introduction of the assets test at the end of next year.

SPEECH.PARA: As well, the whole administrative exercise undertaken by the Department of Social Security has been a waste of time, money and effort as it will have to be duplicated due to the introduction of the new assets test. I will deal with that matter in some detail. As I said, two earlier moves caused considerable concern and distress and were rendered obsolete by Mr Keating's announcement of an assets test. That announcement prompted further widespread confusion, mainly about the Treasurer's reference to possessions to the value of $1,500 and $2,500 being exempt from the assets test.

Concern was expressed also by people who had invested their money at realistic interest rates after receiving advice from financial advisers. They wondered what was to become of them and of their livelihood. As an example, I cite the case of a man who came into my office last week and was concerned about a stock investment he had. The man held 3,000 shares valued at $13,000, but they yielded only a bonus of $50. Is he to be taxed at the notional rate of 10 per cent and be deemed to have received $1,300? If so, taking into account his other investments in Telecom Australia loans and the rest, that would put his income above the allowable limit for a full pension, so he would lose all the existing concessions. Many others in that kind of situation will be caught by the Minister's proposals. Those people are not wealthy. They have been thrifty throughout their lives and have struggled to put money aside for their retirements. I believe that they should not be penalised for that. Indeed, the system should allow incentives for self-provision for retirement where that is possible. The effect of the Government's combined changes will be to destroy all incentives and to penalise thrift and self-provision.

There is no doubt that the changes have caused concern and demonstrated a lack of a comprehensive approach. Such an approach is needed to ensure that the existing systems of income security are studied and any necessary changes to improve their equity and comprehensiveness are made. A Senate inquiry would allow all interested parties to make submissions and present their ideas. The members of the committee would therefore have the advantage of hearing from all sectors-the Government, private industry and the general community-before presenting a report and making recommendations. This would be different from the past practice of government, which has been to announce decisions and then hold discussions to see how the decisions would work out in practice.

In particular we heard Senator Grimes say today that the statements in the Budget in connection with exemptions on assets were in fact a mere statement of intent, that they had nothing to do with a specific undertaking. It could have been made a little clearer both by the Minister and the Treasurer in the Budget Speech if that were the intention. I suspect it was not the intention at that time because such broad statements about exemptions on works of art and jewellery, about two motor cars, boats, caravans, et cetera, are not merely statements of intent but are quite clear in their implications for people. It is a crying shame that people did not have this matter explained to them earlier.

There are other inconsistencies in the statements made by the Minister and the Treasurer in the last few days. It must be acknowledged that on 3 May 1982 Mr Bill Hayden, the then Leader of the Opposition, took to task very severely the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, Phillip Lynch, when he proposed some kind of means test on pensions. Honourable senators may recall very well Mr Hayden's outlandish statement:
It's another kick in the teeth for aged and retired citizens, as well as half a million widows, invalids and supporting parents.
These people, of course, are caught by Labor's assets test. He also said:
Already many aged people this year are being forced to pay income tax for the first time because rising inflation is pushing their pensions above the taxation -free threshold.

Whilst Mr Hayden acknowledged that problem in regard to pensioners in 1982, at the first opportunity the Australian Labor Party had of bringing down a Budget it ignored that point entirely. That will lead to a situation in which people not only will not have their minimum income limits adjusted for inflation but also will find themselves subject to taxation as their pension benefits rise through the impact of indexation in the current financial year. The point is that there is massive confusion in the community about the Government's intentions. I believe that the Government does not know what it intends to do in many of these areas. It is confusing itself. Senator Grimes said last year, referring to the previous Government when it came to office:
It is perfectly clear . . . the Government did not know what it was going to do and how it was going to do it.

That is true of the present Government when it came to office, but it is particularly true that the various statements made by the Government in the last three months have confused the issue to an enormous degree. I quote another gem from Senator Grimes which applies to this area also:

. . . it is just a demonstration of the incapacity of the Minister and the Government to deal with this problem in a reasonable and fair way and to ensure that people who are retired and are eligible for age pensions in this community know what is going on and have some certainty regarding their retirement and some indication that the Government and the Minister know what is going on.

If ever that kind of statement ought to apply then it should apply to the motion which I have moved. Uncertainty and confusion will continue to hold sway until there is an overall examination of retirement income systems. It is for that reason that I hope all honourable senators will support my motion to have this matter referred immediately to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am flattered by Senator Messner's copious quoting of my previous remarks. I suppose one must be flattered, but many of those remarks were quoted out of context and were taken from speeches made in different sets of circumstances. I must say that I have been guilty of that in the past and therefore I will pass it over. Let me take up briefly one point raised by Senator Messner. He seemed to have been very keen on some remarks I made about a Budget of the parties which are now in opposition . They announced that they might make some changes to overcome the problem of people circumventing the income test in existence at that time. As I recall it-I recall it very well-in the Budget Speech and in the statement on social security policy made by Senator Chaney, the then Minister, some concern was expressed at the fact that people were circumventing the income test. For example, people with money in cheque accounts received no interest on that money and therefore were avoiding the income test. He, I think in a musing sort of way, suggested that the Government would do something about that. He did not specify what it would do but suggested that it might limit the amount of money that could be put into an interest-free cheque account to $3,000.

SPEECH.PARA: From then on nothing happened. I remember that for month after month at Question Time Senator Giles, in particular, and I asked Senator Chaney what he was going to do about it and when he would introduce these changes. The pensioners were worried about what he would do and how he would do it. Ultimately Senator Chaney said rather shamefacedly that there might be an election soon so he would do nothing. He did not actually say there would be an election soon, but that is what it was all about. So nothing was done. For some months pensioners were told by Senator Chaney that the then Government did not like what they were doing and that it figured something ought to be done about it. In fact, nothing was done and all that anxiety that Senator Messner talks about now was to no avail.

Senator Messner complained that our making three changes in the pensions area- we announced two changes in the May statement and one in the Budget statement-is the wrong way to go about things. He suggests that they are internally inconsistent and are causing problems. Let me talk about those changes. The first change concerned the treatment of superannuation lump sum payments. The simple fact of the matter is, as was pointed out at the National Economic Summit Conference and as has been pointed out many times in this Parliament and at various seminars and conferences, that the taxation deductions available to superannuees through both the special treatment of lump sums and the special treatment of superannuation premiums in fact cost the revenue some $2,000m a year. Until changes are made the 40 per cent of people who have access to superannuation, but in particular 60 per cent of that 40 per cent, will continue to benefit considerably at the expense of the other 60 per cent of the work force who have no access to superannuation. The main reason for this is that Australia is unique in its special treatment of lump sum superannuation payments .

If we are to introduce a contributory national superannuation scheme, as most people advocate we should, then we have to take heed of the reports of the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry and the Asprey Taxation Review Committee which said that while we have this special treatment of lump sums under the taxation system the introduction of a national superannuation scheme is nigh on impossible. So the first reason for doing something about the situation is the unfair taxation advantages afforded those people, and the second reason is the unfair treatment under the social security legislation of that group of people as distinct from people who receive weekly superannuation payments. So in those two situations something has to be done.

We announced our intention of taking action and we quite clearly said in the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that we would consult with the unions, business and the people affected. We have done that. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, being a responsible organisation, has come to an arrangement with the Government, and many sections of business agree with what the Government has done. Senator Messner should know that large sections of the life insurance and superannuation industry agree with what the Government has done. Of course some people do not agree, such as the airline pilots who work 37 hours a month and have plenty of time to consider what is happening to their wages and their taxation. The fact is that responsible people agree with what has been done.

But that does not solve all our problems; nor did we suggest it would solve all our problems. We never suggested that the only reason to introduce that change was to prevent double dipping. Other people with large amounts in assets who have not received those assets from lump sum superannuation payments still indulge in double dipping through the schemes contrived to avoid the income test , schemes which have blossomed since the previous Government scrubbed the assets test in 1976. What is more, the then Opposition predicted that that would happen . The pensioners federation at that time opposed the removal of the assets test because it predicted what would happen. People with large asset holdings, in both cash and property, have been able to manipulate those holdings so they are not considered as income under the income test and they have had an enormous advantage over people on small fixed weekly incomes or superannuation payments. They have continued to be in this position. While they are in this position, governments of any persuasion will continue to find it very difficult to raise the base rate of pension and to provide the assistance for housing and rented accommodation that is necessary to have a fair pension system. They also make it very difficult for any government to introduce a national superannuation scheme because such a scheme, of whatever kind that is likely to be introduced, must at the time of its introduction consider those who have just retired or are about to retire. It would need to be assisted out of Consolidated Revenue. While people are able to take out of Consolidated Revenue some $250m to $300m each year which they do not need, it will be difficult, to say the least, if not impossible to introduce a national superannuation scheme.

The introduction of an assets test is utterly consistent with our moves made on superannuation lump sums, as is the change to the pension for those of 70 years of age. One remembers that pensioners of 70 years of age and over used to receive a pension completely free of a means or income test. The previous government realised the inequities that existed here and went part of the way by putting an income test on increases in those pensions. The present Government, in an utterly consistent way, extended that to an income test on those aged 70 years and over. It is a very generous income test, a much more generous test than that which aplied to those between 65 and 70 years of age. We realised, as we said in Opposition, that people had prepared for their retirement with that income test in mind and that to introduce a full income test for those between 65 and 69 years of age would have been unfair.

These three changes are utterly internally consistent with each other. They are consistent with the introduction of a national superannuation scheme. They are consistent with the introduction of a rational retirement program in this country. For Senator Messner to suggest that the present difficulty and controversy arose out of something which I or the Treasurer did not say on Budget night, I think, to say the least, is unfair. I accept the fact that there was some confusion. I accept the fact that not in the morning's papers immediately after the Budget, but after that, there was a misinterpretation, which I find hard to understand-I do understand it can happen at Budget time when people have masses of papers to read-of the $1,500 and $2,500 extra income exemption.

But that has been brought to the attention of the public and the pensioners, since we announced on Budget night: 'The final details of how the new test will work in practice will be settled after I have consulted with pensioner organisations'. Given that it has become obvious to pensioners and their organisations that it will take effect 12 months after the legislation comes in. I suggest that there has been and will be an increasing acceptance of what the Government is doing. I make no apologies for not coming into this place and saying: 'Here is what we are going to do. This will be exempt, that will not be exempt, and we are not going to change that view. We will not take any notice of what pensioner organisations and others say'. What we said was: 'We will talk to them and iron out the wrinkles which may arise'.

Almost every example that was given to me on talkback radio last week was that not only would people not be disadvantaged by the assets test but also that some people would be positively advantaged by it. In the six examples which were brought to me by the Australian Pensioners Federation last night only two people would be very disadvantaged, and that was very marginally. The others would be either advantaged or not affected at all. I know that this is a difficult area. I am perfectly aware, as is anybody else in this place, that aged people are not in a position to cope with change as well as others in the community. But the simple fact of the matter is that if we are to make changes of this type-I believe changes of this type need to be made-we will always have this difficulty , particularly if there are people in the community who are willing deliberately to stir up confusion. A government which has been in power since 1975 and which, prior to 1972, was in power for 23 years, I suggest, with the resources and the facilities which it had, should have had some idea of a comprehensive retirement package for the people in this community. Clearly, it did not have such a policy while in government and, clearly, it has not had one in opposition.

We have the extraordinary situation, as has been reported to me, of Senator Messner supporting the executive of the Australian Pensioners Federation which arrived in Canberra with its programs. The Australian Pensioners Federation is a good organisation which is concerned about what is happening. That organisation is in favour of the abolition of the means test. Therefore, it does not like an assets test. If Senator Messner agrees with that organisation, I ask: Does he agree with its policy in totality? The Federation's policy is for the introduction of probate and death duties; the abolition of the dependent spouse rebate; and the introduction of wealth taxes, capital gains taxes and increases in income tax for the high income earners in the community. If Senator Messner is going to be aware of one part of that organisation's policy, I suggest he has to think about the other part, because at least it is consistent. It recognises that if there is no assets test the money has to come from somewhere else.

The Pensioners Federation was willing to put down in a policy, which will be undoubtedly unpopular with many of its members, particularly regarding probate and capital gains tax, how it should be done. Senator Messner just says: 'No, you should not have an assets test'. Nowhere did he talk about the problem of how the funds are to be raised. He ignored the speeches of his own Leader in recent times about the introduction of a means test and an assets test. He came into this Parliament and began nit picking. We have adequate time to sort out any differences and problems that people may have about the assets test. I can tell honourable senators that in the last couple of weeks those suggested problems have been on the margin and most have not been problems at all.

I now turn to Senator Messner's motion. He gave notice in the Senate that he would move that a matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare . It was a very large reference concerning the whole of the income support area for the aged in the community. The Chairman of that Committee was given a copy of the notice of motion 30 seconds before it was put up. The usual courtesies, such as discussing the matter with the Chairman of the Committee and perhaps the Chairman of the Committee discussing with the Committee whether there was a possibility of considering the matter within its program and within the time specified, were not gone through. I suppose that suggests the notice of motion was brought up in a hurry. I would not suggest that Senator Messner would do that out of discourtesy. I suggest the notice of motion was brought up in a hurry and I suggest it may have been brought up for political reasons.

It is clear from Senator Messner's speech here but much clearer from statements which he has made that he intends to use this motion as a vehicle to try to get this chamber to oppose legislation dealing with the assets test and superannuation changes. It is clear that this is a political vehicle which is being wheeled into this place, I suggest, because he fears that the logic and the facts will be against him and, therefore, he will have to get up in this place and say that we cannot pass the legislation because a Senate committee is looking at it, that a Senate committee is examining the situation. I have no worries at all in normal circumstances about a Senate committee or any other committee looking at future retirement incomes policy in this country, although we did have a very lengthy report from the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry some years ago, which I advise Senator Messner to read some time. I suggest this matter was touched on by the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty which looked at it for many years. I suggest it was also looked at by the Asprey Taxation Review Committee and other committees, including the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which had some things to say recently about superannuation funds.

It is my understanding that the Australian Democrats may well support the proposal of Senator Messner to refer this matter to the Committee on Social Welfare. As I say, I will not lose any sleep over that, but I make it perfectly clear that the referral of such a reference to the Committee will not inhibit the Government from introducing the legislative changes it intends to introduce. It will not force this Government to delay the introduction of important reforms for the retirement area for another year, costing the taxpayer some $250m to $ 300m in the case of the assets test-because that is how long it will take to introduce the program-and costing the revenue considerable amounts of money in the area of superannuation, thereby inhibiting important reforms for the low income pensioner and low income people in this community. This merely delaying tactic by Senator Messner will not force this Government to delay the introduction of reforms for those in rental accommodation, of reforms for those who are reliant on the base rate pension and of reforms in other areas of social security.

The Government will oppose the referral of this matter to the Committee, but not because it is concerned about the Committee. We recognise the fact that, with the numbers in this place, this motion will be carried. We will not bother to divide on the issue. We will certainly co-operate with the Committee if the Committee does seek that reference. But in recognition of the fact that the justification for the reference of this matter to the Committee by Senator Messner in his speech today was based on a few misquotations from me when I was shadow Minister for social security, by absolute misrepresentation of the changes of the Government in the areas of superannuation, the 70-year-old pension and the assets test, and recognising that this is a political stunt, we will formally oppose this reference. I hope Senator Messner has the decency to seek an adjournment so he can discuss the matter with the Chairman and members of the Committee. If he does not and it is still referred to the Committee, we will of course co-operate and view the findings with interest if the Committee has time to finalise the matter before 1984. However, that will not inhibit us from introducing the legislation which this country and, in particular, its retired people need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is going to set Senator Grimes's mind at rest, I assure him that I do not intend quoting, in or out of context, anything that anybody on either side of this House has said about an income and assets test, since it has been made patently clear to me over the years that the only political party in this place that ever has to be consistent in anything it says or does is the Australian Democrats. Everybody else can say anything they like one year and something else the next and nobody seems to mind. It may also be of some comfort to Senator Grimes to know that although the Democrats are supporting the Opposition's motion to have the matter of retirement incomes referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, we are doing it on two provisos. The first is that it is the only action open to the Senate if it wishes to have retirement incomes investigated in any way. We would much prefer that an independent public inquiry such as a royal commission, although not necessarily with a judge heading it, be established to look into existing retirement income systems and possibly to make recommendations for the future. Because that is not within the bounds of the Senate I seek to amend Senator Messner's motion. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph 1, after 'That', insert the following words: ', although it may be that a more appropriate forum for an examination of existing retirement income systems would be an independent public inquiry such as a Royal Commission,'.
If the amendment were accepted the motion before the Senate would then read:

(1) That, although it may be that a more appropriate forum for an examination of existing retirement income systems would be an independent public inquiry such as a Royal Commission, the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare: Existing retirement income systems, with particular reference to any changes which may be necessary to ensure equitable and comprehensive income security for Australians of retirement age.
Paragraph (2) would be unaffected and would continue to read:
(2) That the Committee report to the Senate on or before the first sitting day in August 1984.

The second proviso is that our support of this motion referring the matter to a Senate standing committee is not to be taken as any indication that the Australian Democrats oppose the principle of the Government's proposal to introduce an assets and income test. Senator Grimes has suggested that this may be one way in which the Liberal Opposition is attempting to delay the passage of the legislation to bring into effect the Government's proposals for an assets and income test. Previous action on the part of the Liberal Party in this chamber has indicated that it does not make much difference to it whether the legislation has been introduced or not, or has been passed or not. If it suits the fancy of the Liberal Party it will refer the proposals to a committee, as it did with the withholding tax, which not only was based on its own legislation but which it supported with some enthusiasm in the Senate in June.

Perhaps Senator Grimes can be soothed by the notion that there is nothing machiavellian-political, yes, but nothing machiavellian-about the Liberals' reference of this matter to a committee. The pretzel antics that members of the Liberal Party engage in never cease to amaze me. Having spent something like seven years displaying little else but intellectual atrophy and legislative inertia they have now decided that they are passionately concerned about pensioners and about the plight of the aged generally. After ignoring the recommendations of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, after shelving for something like seven years the report of the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry on a national portable contributory superannuation scheme, the Liberal Party has now decided that the plight of people affected by limited incomes in their retirement should again be studied in depth, and this time, by a Senate committee. The Liberal Party is now talking about shameful attacks on pensioners, after supporting in June the means test legislation relating to pensions for the over 70s. It is now talking about repealing any assets and income legislation which passes through the Parliament this year, if and when it is ever re-elected, after going on the record, as Senator Grimes has pointed out, in recent years as supporting such an assets test as being necessary for equity and to avoid double dipping. Indeed, I understand that at the Victorian Liberal Party conference early this year just such a motion was passed. I find the Liberal behaviour breathtakingly sanctimonious.

The Australian Democrats support, as I understand, most thinking people do, the implementation at the earliest possible date of a national portable contributory superannuation scheme. We believe that a secure income in old age should be a right, not a handout; that it is necessary not only for the physical well-being of most people in their old age but also for their psychological well-being. We believe it is the only way in which an equitable and secure income can be achieved for people over retirement age. As I have said, the Liberal Party did nothing during its last seven years in government to implement either of those things. During the Menzies era it managed by slight of hand to take back into the Consolidated Revenue Fund, back into the taxation structure, the element of taxation that was specifically set aside for social welfare payments. It then went on in succeeding years to imply that the pension was a handout for those who had not managed to do well enough for themselves during their working lives. Instead of playing politics over the assets and income proposal the Government has introduced, I suggest that the energies of the Liberal Party would have been far better used in attempting to remove the inequities and anomalies that exist in the embryonic proposals the Government has brought forward.

Senator Townley raised during Question Time today the question that has been raised by most people phoning my office, and that is the matter of a holiday home or a shack down by the beach or whatever, which was for some reason omitted from the examples given by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on Budget night. These sorts of things are able to be negotiated. The Government has taken a responsible step in insisting that it will not be bringing forward the legislation in any definitive form until all concerned groups have been consulted and until the reasonable suggestions of those groups have been incorporated.

Having moved my amendment to Senator Messner's motion I repeat that we see no harm in referring the matter of retirement incomes to a Senate committee. We believe that an independent public inquiry, such as a royal commission, would be a more appropriate forum, but we accept that it is not within the Senate's powers to do that. It is something like seven or eight years since the Hancock report on superannuation and the Henderson report on poverty were brought down. We hope that this Committee will bring those reports up to date and that it will enable the community to discuss the needs of people after they have retired with a view to establishing some sort of reasonable minimum income which is fair and equitable for those people. We hope that it will not be used by the Liberal Party as some political ploy or grandstanding exercise, producing, for instance, a Liberal minority report that it will wave about under the nose of the electorate come election time. If the electorate believes that a future Liberal government would ever repeal an assets and income test which has saved the Government money, it will believe anything. The Australian Democrats support, with our amendement, the motion put forward by Senator Messner in the hope that it will produce some relevant and valuable recommendations relating to post- retirement income, particularly the implementation of a national portable contributory superannuation scheme, and that it will not be used as a political grandstanding exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —When consideration was adjourned, I had just started to talk about my amendments to clause 17 of the Bill. Practising lawyers tell us time and again that it is extremely difficult in matrimonial proceedings , actions for damages or any other proceedings to get the parties to face up to a realistic compromise unless in some way or other there is pressure on them to face what one might call reality. It does not matter that they go before legal advisers who are able to tell them within 1 or 2 per cent the sum of money they may get or the settlement that the court will most probably direct. It is a fact of life that the parties tend to live in a dream world until they face a hurdle that they have to leap and then they apply their minds realistically. They take advice and guidance and suddenly the action will be compromised. That happens so often in the running down jurisdiction that judges will sometimes have three or four actions listed for hearing on one day. Senators may ask how the court could possibly hear three or four actions on the one day. In fact, what happens is that by 11 o'clock in the morning all three or four actions have been compromised and the judge finds himself with the rest of the day, or the rest of the morning off depending upon his program. That is not for any sinister reason but simply because the parties so frequently fail to face up to the reality of life until they actually have to go into the court to fight the case. They then start to seek some reasonable compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: It seemed to me that that hurdle might be used in order to bring about some solution of the almost eternal arguments which go on about maintenance and property settlements and also custody. I, then, have put forward the proposal that before the parties can receive a decree nisi they must have settled or had litigated questions of property, maintenance and custody. That is the purpose of the amendments. I recognise that parties may endeavour to use such a procedure to delay the decree nisi being granted. I realise that some parties who do not want a divorce to go through will take any steps possible to prevent it. So I have suggested that, as a result of the amendments, the court should have the power to order that the divorce proceedings shall come on for hearing, if it is satisfied that they should. I have made the provision very wide.

I also recognised that, unless the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) saw some merit in these proposals, probably they would not go through. So I put the amendments to the Attorney-General. He has been kind enough to give me a paper which was prepared in his office and which he will no doubt elaborate on in some way after I finish speaking. There are some things in that paper to which I would like to refer. I am a little unsure whether I should have my say about the paper at this stage or I can ask the Attorney-General to express his views first and then respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it been distributed?
—No, it has not so I will allow the Attorney-General to speak on the matter first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Lewis's invitation I say that the Government's attitude is one of opposition to the package of amendments proposed by him. It of course appreciates that Senator Lewis has put forward his suggestions in good faith and in a desire to expedite the Family Law Amendment Bill and make it more efficient, in the interests of the system as a whole and of the parties themselves, dealing with the procedure for dissolutions and the accompanying ancillary matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem we see with it is both practical and, to some extent, philosophical . One of the main policy changes that the original Family Law Act, which we are seeking to amend here today, aimed to achieve was ensuring that the divorce proceedings and the related custody or financial proceedings were dealt with completely separately. Under the previous matrimonial causes system, the divorce petition had simultaneously to seek the custody and financial orders sought by the petitioner and all matters were, as a matter of course, dealt with together. This led to the situation of matters being artificially defended-often for blackmail purposes-with unreasonable demands being made. A party would continue to defend a matter in the hope that the other party, who might have been anxious to remarry, would agree, as a result, to a higher financial settlement. That was an intrinsic part and parcel of the way the system operated. The present system is, to some extent, a reaction to that. It is a desire to separate the fact of the divorce from the associated proceedings. It is also a question of practicalities. I am told-this has been discussed with Justice Fogarty, the present Chairman of the Family Law Council who I understand has had some discussions with the Council about this-that the old system became bogged down by delays and many of the abuses that were associated with the old system were a function of all these matters being heard together in this way.

The system that applies under the current legislation is that a divorce can be granted, and usually is, within a few months of the filing of the application, but in property settlement matters the delay between filing and hearing can be up to two years. What would happen as a result of Senator Lewis's proposal being accepted would be that in a great many cases it would undoubtedly take up to two years from the date of the application was filed to gain a divorce. That date would, of course, in turn be at least three years from the date of the separation. Senator Lewis seems to have anticipated the blackmail arguments. He would overcome this by giving the Family Court of Australia a wide discretion to dispense with the general requirement in an appropriate case. But as has been pointed out to me and to my officers who have been in consultation with the judiciary on this, a wide discretion to dispense with the requirement would inevitably result in a multitude of such applications being made, if not in every case. What we would have would be an overloaded system becoming further bogged down.

I understand that the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act gave some consideration to this kind of proposal and decided that, where possible, all issues between divorcing parties should be settled before the divorce was granted. That is an understandable aspiration. However, the Committee went on to say that it was opposed to procedural changes that would make the divorce decree in all cases dependent on the resolution of other issues until the Court's services were improved to the point where all matters, ancillary and principal, could be dealt with within a reasonable period. That was indicated to be no more than three months after the separation period had elapsed. While one can accept the basis in principle for that particular position, the practical foundation for it simply cannot be accomplished. It would be just impossible to achieve, however much we might like to hope that it would be achievable.

Finally, there is one other small point that I would like to mention. I do not have an actual paper in front of me. I am simply speaking from notes based on consultations with the judiciary. Some of the other recommendations that we are seeking to adopt as a result of the deliberations of the Joint Select Committee erode the principle of finality with respect to orders in financial proceedings. We want to make provision-we will deal with this later on-for setting aside property orders under section 79A, widening the grounds for approval of maintenance agreements under section 87 and so on. As a result, we want a situation in which there is, at least in some repects related to property and financial matters, a continuing supervision by the Court.

I suggest that it is rather at odds with this kind of policy development which I think most people would see to be an appropriate one, that we should be, by other means-I suggest essentially artificial means-seeking to impose finality.

It is important to get the parties to the barrier to appreciate the realities of the situation which they are in, to concentrate their minds on the necessity to reach an accommodation between themselves without relying ultimately on the Court to make all the decisions for them. That is an aspiration which Senator Lewis has expressed. I share every one of those sentiments. I just think it would be impossible. The Government has reviewed the situation pretty carefully since Senator Lewis put these matters before it but does not think it would be an appropriate way of solving what is obviously still a serious practical problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I support the argument advanced by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). Many members of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act hoped that they might be able to find a way whereby things could be dealt with at the one time. One recognises what Senator Lewis has said about ordinary litigation. Certainly, things can be speeded up. If people know that they have to negotiate and proceed, they will do that at an early stage. It was obvious, after the evidence we called, that it was quite impractical to suggest that we could lay down rules without doing a great deal of injustice to people and having a situation in which a divorce may be considerably delayed. People would thereby not have the opportunity of sorting out their household arrangements. Remarrying and getting the children into a situation may well be held up for a considerable period if all ancillary matters have to be settled at the same time. Clearly that has never been possible. The money that would need to be expended by the Government in providing so many extra judges, registrars and so forth would be quite considerable and very often , of course, it is not desirable that all the property matters and so forth should be settled quickly, in some helter-skelter way. After the heat has died down very often the parties come to a more reasonable situation. This type of idea was certainly thrown around quite a lot in the deliberations of the Committee and in the evidence given to it but it was not thought to be a practical solution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should respond to a couple of matters which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) raised. For example, he said right at the beginning that one of the purposes of this legislation is to separate matters of custody and financial proceedings from the actual divorce. There is nothing in my proposed amendment which would do anything towards not separating them. I do not see any reason why there has to be some sort of hearing at which these matters would be argued together. While I recognise the problems which originally existed under the old system when these matters were all dealt with together and, of course, there was an argument as to whether a divorce ought to be granted, I do not see that that would really apply in the way the Bill is framed at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General also said something which went along the lines that under the new system a divorce can be granted within a few months and usually is. I want to say seriously to the Senate and to the Attorney-General that there are many people in this community who do not believe that that is an ideal situation . Many people in this community believe that once a couple have entered upon the role of being married, have made their vows each to the other, they ought not to be able to rapidly escape those vows in order to get into some other matrimonial situation and then, after they have done all that, start to sort out the problems of their children, the custody of their children, their financial relationships, who is to care for the former wife, how they will divide up the assets that they have acquired over their married life, and so on. Many people in this community think that a couple who have been married for many years ought to give deep consideration to these matters before the divorce is rapidly pushed through.

In particular I think of the situation of a wife married for 25 or 30 years or even more who, of course, is way beyond her working expectancy. She has spent up to 25 or 30 years keeping a home and raising children. She could not possibly be expected to go back into the work force. Her husband can walk out of that arrangement and walk into an affair with some other woman and be divorced within a very short time-as Senator Gareth Evans says, usually within a few months of filing the application. Within 15 months of the husband walking out of a marriage which has existed for 25 years or more, she can find herself in a situation in which her husband has remarried and at that stage they are to have an argument about what will be the financial arrangements between them. Many people in this community are of the view, as am I, that those matters ought to be resolved before the husband is able to escape the vows that he entered into so solemnly at the time of the marriage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be the other way round, of course.

—As Senator Colston says, it could be the other way round. The husband may find that after 25 years or so his wife has left him. This means that perhaps he has to live the rest of his life by himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Could I indicate briefly that I believe that any amendment that attempts to focus the attention of persons who propose to or have filed an application for the dissolution of a marriage on all the consequences of that action, the legal and social consequences, ought to be supported. Their attention should be directed to the legal consequences of that action, to the social consequences of that action and to the consequences on their children and on the property of the marriage. SPEECH.PARA: I agree with what Senator Lewis has said about the fact that situations can arise whereby these consequences are not faced. People do run away from the consequences. Before they realise the consequences, or are made to realise the consequences by reason of their having to face the facts in the courts or elsewhere, they jump into another engagement or another proposed marriage. The original problem is left unsolved. In many instances they take the problems away with them. In most instances the problem does not go away. As I mentioned on the previous occasion and will mention again shortly, the incidence of divorce on remarriage in this country is now 50 per cent. That is an enormous burden that is placed on individuals and the community. There are social consequences of these actions and they ought to be faced. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply indicate that the Government is unmoved by the rather stern brand of morality which has been expressed by both Senator Lewis and Senator Harradine in their contributions to this debate. There are many situations in which the innocent party, to use Senator Harradine's terminology, feels deeply and desperately trapped inside an unhappy marriage. It is that innocent party-who may be a woman who has been much put upon for many years of unhappiness by a brutally inclined spouse-who just wants to escape from the relationship and all its legal consequences as fast as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is any kind of complexity associated with a couple's financial and property arrangements it is impossible to conceive, with the court resources being as they are at this moment, matters of this kind being able to be resolved in less than the 18 months or two years that they take at the moment. All that will happen as a result of the passage of Senator Lewis's amendment is that an enormous amount of pressure will be able to be imposed on the weaker of the two parties in that situation to accept a settlement that may be less than fair in all the circumstances in order to enable that person to escape from the legal trappings that they feel enslave them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to correct Senator Evans. I made no mention of innocent parties, nor did I make any mention of stern morality. I made no statement about morality either stern or otherwise. TALK.START.PARA: — At this stage I intend to move amendment No . (18) in the consolidated list. I point out that I will move amendment No. (19) before I move amendment No. (17) because obviously if No. (19) is carried it may not be necessary to move No. (17). I move:

''and (d) by adding at the end thereof the following sub-sections:

'(5) The Court shall grant leave under this section where refusal to grant that leave would impose severe hardship on the applicant.

'(6) In determining an application for leave to institute proceedings under this section, the Court shall have regard to the interests of any children of the marriage and to the question of whether there is any reasonable likelihood of a reconciliation between the parties before the expiration of a period of three years after the date of the marriage.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can indicate why it is that Senator Harradine's proposal, for which he will advance arguments in a moment, is unacceptable to the Government. What is being proposed is that in relation to marriages of short duration-those less than three years old at the date the proceedings for disolution are instituted-the disolution proceedings not be instituted without the initial leave of the Family Court being sought. The Court is supposed, in determining such a leave application, to have regard to the interests of any children of the marriage and the question of whether there is any reasonable likelihood of a reconciliation between the parties before the expiration of a period of three years after the date of the marriage. So what we are imposing here is an additional stage of formal court proceedings. One has to satisfy a judge before one can go ahead with the divorce if it has been a short marriage, even though one has satisfied the condition of separation for 12 months as evidence of the irretrievable breakdown of that marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: As such, the general approach underlying Senator Harradine's proposition is quite inconsistent with the existing philosophy of the legislation. Moreover, we believe it is quite impractical to the extent that it imposes a very substantial additional burden on court time and, of course, will add considerably to the costs of the parties. If it is thought that there is something to be said for ensuring that the parties to marriages of short duration give more attention to the possibility of reconciliation than might otherwise be the case, there may be something to be said for expanding the requirement for counselling before the matter proceeds. We have had some debate already, and I think it has been accepted, that such counselling should take place before petitions are filed in relation to marriages of less than two years duration at the time the petition is filed. It may be that there is something to be said by way of compromise for extending to marriages of three years duration that requirement for compulsory counselling before the filing of an application.

That is something that Senator Harradine might bear in mind. I say that not in any great spirit of confidence about the likely success of counselling enterprises but because it is a recognised fact that in many marriages of short duration the parties are perhaps inclined to jump too readily into divorce to the detriment of the best interests of their children without really considering the chances of reconciliation. To the extent that Senator Harradine is concerned about that, as well he might be, maybe something ought to be done about it. But to impose, as Senator Harradine proposes, a compulsory requirement for the Court really to make some determination, presumably on the basis of full evidence before it, on all the matters he would wish the Court to have regard to seems to us to add a quite unrealistic new layer to the family law process.

To the extent that Senator Harradine's proposal is based on present provisions in the United Kingdom, as I suspect it might be, I wish to draw his attention to some recent developments in that country. At present section 3 of the United Kingdom Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 prevents a petition for divorce being presented within three years of marriage unless the court is satisfied that the case is one of exceptional hardship for the petitioner or that there has been what is described as exceptional depravity by the respondent. It has now been proposed by a Law Commission report entitled 'Time Restrictions on the Presentation of Divorce and Nullity Petitions' that that present provision be replaced with an absolute bar on the presentation of petitions within the first year of marriage; in other words, to bring it back to something like the kind of situation we have here in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the English law reform commission?

—Yes. The reference, if anyone is interested, is Law Commission Report No. 116, which was tabled in the House of Commons on 20 October 1982. Several important points are made, but I will not endeavour to summarise this in any elaborate detail. It is said at page 5 of the report that the United Kingdom experience of the three-year restriction as it has operated to date was that it simply deferred rather than deterred divorce, that it did not have that deterrent effect that Senator Harradine undoubtedly hopes it would . A further point is made that in Scotland there has never been a three-year restriction yet there is little variation in the divorce rates between England and Scotland, suggesting, says the Commission, there is no casual connection between the lack of restriction and a high incidence of divorce in the early years of marriage. I suggest that that is a significant finding. It is further argued that there is an obvious theoretical inconsistency between the ground of irretrievable breakdown of marriage on the one hand and the restriction on petitions in the early years of marriage on the other. That point, of course, can be made with a great deal of vigour in the Australian context to the extent that our legislation, with substantial evident majority support, does focus on that criterion of irretrievable breakdown.

SPEECH.PARA: So I would suggest that although Senator Harradine's amendment is undoubtedly motivated, as indeed are all his contributions to this debate, by a concern to ensure that the bonds of matrimony are not lightly broken, particularly perhaps by younger people, who may well need some additional incentive to make them focus on the implications of their behaviour and the consequences of their breaking a marriage relationship, I simply suggest that the evidence from England, and indeed the practicalities of doing this in Australia, militate against the acceptance of this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Committee.
