SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I present the official report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Indonesia, and seek leave to move a motion in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I wish to place on record the Delegation's thanks to the various people and organisations that provided assistance to the Delegation during the course of its visit to Indonesia. This has been recorded within the text of the report. Before commenting on the report I want to make two comments on the introductory comments therein of the leader of the Delegation. I question the ethics of using the Delegation's report to attack my dissenting report. In my view such remarks should have been in Mr Morrison's tabling statement. His assertion is that two quotations used in my dissent do not in fact appear in the Delegation's report. Both quotations appear in the draft of Mr Morrison's introductory comments, supplied to me with the final draft of the report. In order that honourable senators may see the difference between the tabled document and the draft that I received, I will quote the relevant parts of that draft, given to me as the Chairman's proposed introductory comments. I was given to understand that these introductory remarks would appear unchanged in the tabled report. In fact, the remarks were changed prior to the printing of the report. However, my dissent does not rest on these two quotations alone. The first is:

As a fact finding mission the Delegation in the Report records what the Delegation did, the discussions it had and the evaluations and observations made . The Report does not contain any formal recommendations on policy. The Delegation regarded its main purpose as describing to the best of its ability the situation in East Timor. The Delegation's findings are recorded in Chapter 8 which puts into perspective many of the conflicting claims and counter claims associated with the issue. The many discussions the Delegation held are fully recorded. Commentators have the opportunity of making their own evaluations from these extensive records which are incorporated in the Report.
The second comment quoted from the introductory report given to me was:

For a variety of reasons many Australians have taken issue with Indonesia over East Timor and regard the issue as the sole determinant of relations with Indonesia. There is a moral issue involved in the principles espoused by the Fretilin supporters in Australia.
I think that is sufficient to demonstrate what I referred to in my dissenting report. Now it is on record and everyone can judge for himself.

It is with great reluctance that I have felt obliged to submit a dissenting report on the Delegation's recent visit to Indonesia and East Timor. At the outset I wish to stress that I am dissenting not merely because I disagree with the general thrust of the report, but because I do not believe that its approach will serve the best interests of the Australian-Indonesian relationship and not least the interests of the Timorese themselves. In assessing my position in this matter, I have taken into account the potential impact of the report not only on Australian Government policy, but perhaps even on the attitudes of other nations towards the East Timor question.

In these circumstances, I feel that I should first outline the conditions in which the report was considered. The draft was first made available to the Delegation at 2.30 p.m. on Wednesday 17 August, and we immediately launched into a paragraph by paragraph examination of it. There were many differences of opinion and amendments on which, as it happened, voting turned out to be unnecessary. Consideration of the report continued on the morning of the following day and a vote was taken on the amended version. It seemed that there was strong pressure to meet an early deadline. As it turned out, it was only during the following weekend that delegation members had an opportunity to make a careful examination of the amended report, and it was only then that I was able to comprehend fully its substance and implications. In the circumstances, I was not going to be held to a decision made in haste, a decision with profound implications in relation to our understanding of principles of fundamental importance to international relations in general, and to the basic human rights of the East Timorese people in particular.

I do not argue with the proposition that Australians should be urged to understand Indonesia's attitude to the East Timor question, and indeed, circumspectly to consider this question within the sensitive context of the overall Australian-Indonesian relationship. However, there is an even wider context in which this issue should be considered. As a founding member of the United Nations and a co-sponsor of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Australia has a special obligation to heed and advance the principles expressed in those documents. On this basis, Australia has condemned, admittedly somewhat selectively, violations by certain governments of the human rights of others, and has in a number of cases been prepared to resort to such measures as the imposition of sanctions or trade embargoes.

It is of obvious importance that we should strive for an understanding and friendly relationship with out neighbour, Indonesia, but the objective reality is that if such a relationship is to contribute to regional stability, our friendship must be based on a foundation of mutual respect, honesty and frankness, and not least on an acceptance that serious policy differences may arise on specific issues from time to time. In some areas of foreign policy this situation already exists. For example, Australia does not recognise the Pol Pot regime in Kampuchea. Indonesia, on the other hand, does. Indonesian policies and attitudes towards the People's Republic of China differ markedly from those of Australia, as well as those of her Association of South East Asian Nations partners and the United States of America.

Such differences are normal in intercourse between states and, in a mature relationship, there is no risk of their weakening the bonds that bind together the fundamental common interests, let alone giving rise to the risk of armed conflict. The risk of having to face differences or disputes should not deter us from the pursuit of our common objectives in the field of human rights and regional security. The accommodation of certain differences with Indonesia within the framework of a developing, caring relationship is more than a challenge; it signifies a measure of our integrity, the consistency of our foreign policy and our maturity as a responsible, independent nation state.

For Australians then, there is more to the problem of East Timor than the position of the Timorese themselves, although their rights must be the focus of our concern when we are talking about human rights. Several lessons emerging from our experience and performance as a middle power over the past nine years raise fundamentally important questions about Australia's role in the region, about how we perceive our commitment to the principles and rights enshrined in the United Nations Charter, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and to several other specific instruments of essential importance to the civilised conduct of relations between states. Not least there is the compelling question of what aims and goals motivate our political relationships with other nations in this region with whom circumstances of geography have, in a sense, imposed on us a shared destiny in a troubled and divided world. It is against these considerations that I believe that, if the price of friendship with Indonesia is to be the abandoning or even qualifying of Australia's long-standing commitment to the principles of self-determination and other human rights, as would be implicit in the accommodation of Indonesia's seizure of East Timor, the foundations on which we are building that important relationship are inappropriate, insecure and plain hazardous.

But let us return to the report itself. In my assessment it manifests a clear tendency to diminish the significance of fundamentally important aspects of the Timor problem, and it contains some quite misleading comments and perceptions. For one thing, it clearly distorts the nature of support for the East Timorese in Australia. In one example it refers to 'the principles espoused by the Fretilin supporters in Australia' which obscures the important fact-one that again and again must be drawn to Indonesia's attention-that most of the support coming from the people of this country is not focused specifically on Fretilin but on the East Timorese people themselves. Indeed, the results of an ANOP poll on 2 June this year showed that 41 per cent of Australians support the right of the East Timorese to self-determination, while only 16 per cent support integration with Indonesia. This pattern is corroborated by the flow of mail coming into my office on this subject. But for most Australians who are concerned at what has happened in the former Portuguese colony, the extent and the nature of the armed resistance to Indonesian rule is only one aspect of a situation which involves fundamentally important humanitarian considerations, based, as I have already indicated, on international principles to which this country is a party.

I do not dispute the conclusion in the report that Indonesia is spending a considerable amount of money in East Timor on the development of the territory's infrastructure and on material conditions. However, in my view the Delegation was unable to determine the extent to which this development is benefiting the Timorese people themselves. Obviously some of these infrastructural improvements have important security implications-that is to say, they are designed to strengthen the capacity of Indonesia's armed and security forces to deal with opposition to their presence in East Timor. Furthermore, the report avoids what must surely be the central human rights issue, and that is, the attitude of the Timorese people to their present circumstances. it is, of course, true that it would have been impossible to make this assessment during our brief visit to the territory and with the limited facilities available to us. Subsequent reports from sources in Indonesia, in Portugal, and in Australia, even as recently as today, cast serious doubt on the credibility of observations in the report in relation to the security situation and to the conditions under which the people are living.

I was initially honoured to be invited to visit Indonesia and East Timor as part of the Delegation. I was subsequently tempted to the conclusion that this invitation was extended within the context of a cynical exercise designed to strengthen the legitimacy of certain views and conclusions held by other members of the Delegation, in some cases, I regret to say, long before the mission went to Indonesia. I am gravely concerned at the fact that this is the report of a parliamentary delegation, not a Government mission. This should have placed on us an especially heavy responsibility in that a report of this kind should be regarded as an expression of the Australian conscience rather than of our political inclinations. In the circumstances I do not regard it as a credible reflection of the views of this Parliament, let alone of the Australian political conscience. Indeed, I believe that it will not enhance this institution's integrity among the parliaments of the democratic world.

I finish by reminding honourable senators that Australia was a founding member of the United Nations. In 1948 we helped to draft the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Since then our position has been fairly consistent. No matter what anyone says about the seizure of East Timor, it was an illegal act. I do not intend to transgress in any way from the fact that it was an illegal act and I do not recognise de jure recognition of the incorporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I wish to speak to the official report which has been tabled by the Parliamentary Delegation to Indonesia. It is difficult in 15 minutes to cover such an enormous subject. Principally I wish to speak of Timor and the dissenting report that has been put by one member of the Delegation out of five. First it is well to canvass the great importance of Australian-Indonesian relations. Indonesia has a population of about 150 million people and is our nearest neighbour. It is hard to imagine two countries that have greater differences and yet live side by side than Australia and Indonesia. The cultural differences-Javanese culture goes back 2,000 years-the historical development that has taken place so differently in both lands, the great ethnic diversity and the great religious diversities make relations between the two countries very difficult. Australia is a cohesive society socially and has a federal government whereas Indonesia, geographically, comprises over 3,000 islands. It has a wide range of ethnic groups and a wide range of religions. The great advantage of the Sukarno years was that he united that very diverse country, those very diverse races. He made a unified nation out of it. He also sent that nation broke. Since the Suharto regime came along we have seen some worthwhile developments take place.
—But it is still under a military dictatorship.

—As Senator Georges says, the complexities of the relationships are such that only a very few people in both countries can understand them; they are so complex and diverse. The purpose of this Delegation was to look at the present situation in Indonesia-not to inquire into history, least of all to inquire into what might have happened in Timor in the past. For those people who challenge the point, as Senator McIntosh does, it must be stated that Australia granted de facto recognition of the incorporation of Timor into Indonesia in 1978 and de jure recognition of Timor and its incorporation into Indonesia in 1979. That is the legal fact of the matter at present. It is not an issue now. It was not an issue for the Delegation to discuss.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that all delegations have limitations, but this Delegation had one enormous advantage. It was the first parliamentary delegation into Indonesia and Timor since Timor was incorporated. As the Senate inquiry into human rights in Timor ascertained, the paucity of recent information is striking. That is what has made the Senate's inquiry a joke. There we are dealing with hearsay information which is seven years or eight years old. The great advantage of this Parliamentary Delegation was that we went there. While we might not have seen everything, we are in an infinitely better position to comment on it than any other source. Apart from a few journalists who have gone in during the last 12 months, and Mr Gough Whitlam, there has been no informed visit to Timor from the outside world.

The Indonesian Government co-operated with the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the limit of its ability. In fact, it gave us everything we asked for. I will start with the interpreters because they play a crucial role. We have several languages to deal with: English, Bahasa Indonesia, Portuguese and Tetum. The Australian Department of Foreign Affairs provided the Bahasa Indonesia translators for us and for the critical task of translation of Portuguese and Tetum we had the choice of who we had and we made our selection. In fact Senator McIntosh made the selection of the interpreters he wanted. One was a Mr Moura, a Portuguese who had been gaoled for some considerable period by the Indonesians after the troubles in 1975, and the other was a representative from the International Committee of the Red Cross.

The Indonesians gave us five days in East Timor, six days if we include the day in west Timor. The period of the Delegation was extended from the usual five days in Indonesia to a total of ten. I have seen incorrect comment in the Australian Press that no members were allowed to visit Timor with us. That is quite incorrect because three representatives-from Radio Australia, Australian Associated Press and the Sydney Morning Herald-were with the delegation. I believe that an open invitation to the Press was given, albeit at a late date. Those journalists accompanied us wherever they wanted to go and they were present at all interviews.

I will deal briefly with conditions in Indonesia because it was a delegation to Indonesia. Indonesia is not a wealthy country. It is a developing country. Oil plays the dominant part in its export earnings. It is a country dominated by two factors: Its island geography and its high population density. In fact it has the highest population density in the world. There are one million new jobs to be found each year in Java alone with its population of 80 million. The combination of high population densities, relatively low level of education of the community and the geographic distribution provide major problems for Indonesia's development. We were all very impressed with the calibre of the Ministers. The members of the parliament we met impressed us as being competent and sincere people.

I now turn to Timor, which has bedevilled Indonesian-Australian relations in recent years. A great deal of international propaganda has been put about designed to damage Indonesian-Australian relations. Some of that is clearly the product of the left wing-the extreme Left-and some of it is the product of well- meaning but ignorant or uninformed people. I will talk to those people in the second category-those well-meaning people who are not informed and who are encouraging the few members of Fretilin left in Timor to struggle on in the belief that there is a large body of the Australian community that will support them. That is not true and it is a very immoral position for those people to take.

Timor is an extraordinarily backward place. It was a Portuguese colony, and the Portuguese would have to be the worst colonists in history. It has some of the most difficult terrain, comparable with the highlands of Papua New Guinea, which imposes enormous transport difficulties. The people have a very high degree of illiteracy and there are public health problems. They are a tribal society and they live on a subsistence economy. What they grow, they eat. If they do not grow crops due to bad seasons or through ill health then they die because there is no alternative source of food.

The Delegation formed the general impression that the administration of East Timor was a very concerned one, as the report shows. We saw no signs of excessive force or authority. We saw a lot of development going on. It is not, as some of the apologists for Fretilin have said, a matter of re-painting old Portuguese schools and buildings and things like that. That is not true. It is quite incorrect for Senator McIntosh to claim that we were not able to assess the value of the great Indonesian development that is going on. What Indonesia is doing from a developmental point of view is worth while. We saw 570 new houses in Dili alone, and I do not think the Portuguese built too many new houses each year when they were there. We saw food production increasing. We saw schooling expanding to a great degree. The present Governor, Mario Carrascalao, is the tenth graduate from a university in 400 years of Portuguese rule. Public health measures are coming on. Communications, in the form of roads and telephones, are being developed. Above all, we saw an ordered society. Timor has a very mountainous terrain with a tribal society. If honourable senators have read Sir Bede Callinan's book on the Independent Company of the Australian commando unit that was there through the war, they will get some insight into the social structure that has existed for some thousands of years. They are a very quiet and passive people but when they get stirred up they murder with great ferocity. Until those people are taken out of the hills, put in suburbia, anaesthetised with television and given Holden cars to drive there will always be pockets of resistance and violence irrespective of what the government of the day is.

I will now deal with the popular misconception that Fretilin controls large areas of Timor. The Senate Committee has been told-if honourable senators talk to people about this and read articles in the Press this is what they will hear- that the popular mythology in Australia is that Fretilin controls large areas of towns and districts in Timor, that it has 20,000 troops, that it is the true government and that it is supported by the great mass of the people. From what we saw none of those allegations are true or supportable in any way at all. Fretilin very clearly controls no areas of Timor. It controls no towns and no villages. It certainly does not have 20,000 troops. The true number would be between 600 to 1,000 in isolated pockets, with very poor communications in the hills. Those troops certainly do not have popular support. Whatever might have been the story in 1974 or 1975, the time has changed and Fretilin is now very much a disorganised minority group. Because of these misconceptions it is worth reflecting upon the origins of Fretilin. It was modelled on the Frelimo organisation, a terrorist organisation in Angola and Mozambique. It is a left wing organisation. It included everyone from moderate socialists through to extreme Marxists. It is comparable, as a body in its operations in Timor although it is not as bad as, the Khmer Rouge and the Pol Pot regime. The story is just not true that Fretilin is the blue-eyed nationalist movement, never having done any harm to anyone. It was a lawless, undisciplined bunch in many of its units and operations.

But there is no problem of security at present in Indonesia. I will instance two examples of that. We flew everywhere by Indonesian Army helicopters at 500 feet above the terrain on direct tracks. We took no evasive action. We travelled in road convoys without escorts and we travelled by day and by night. If there was a threat from Fretilin guerrillas the Indonesians would not have taken that risk. More importantly, because the Indonesians were unconcerned about the risk factor clearly they had had peace for some months.

I now turn to the question of the minority report from Senator McIntosh. Four of the five members of the Delegation support this report. As honourable senators will learn from reading Mr Morrison's letter of transmission, Senator McIntosh agreed with this report. We had total agreement from him. Without putting too fine a point on it, if honourable senators read Mr Morrison's letter they will find an inference that maybe Senator McIntosh did not write parts of that letter of dissent. I am disappointed in the views of Senator McIntosh because I think he has failed to act objectively in the interests of the Australian nation. He had a great responsibility upon him. He had a point of view, which he stated quite publicly before he went to Jakarta, of his opposition to Indonesia and to the Indonesian administration of Timor. I believe that he went there with a closed mind to create trouble for Australian- Indonesian relations and that he used the Delegation's visit as a vehicle for that.

In conclusion I pay tribute to the support we had from the Australian Embassy and other staff members. I thank my colleagues, Mr Dobie, who assisted me as the Liberal Party representative on the Delegation, Mr Cross and Mr Morrison. I was very proud to be part of a delegation led by Mr Morrison. At all times he acted with the highest level of professional skill, as one would expect from a former officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs, and he did Australia very proud in the way he led that delegation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

There are few meal times and no common free evenings for the two chambers. As we indicated at the time the Government laid down these sitting hours, we believe that they are not very efficient. We believe that they will be a great burden to the Government-they are certainly a burden to the Opposition- and that they will interfere with the effective functioning of both party and parliamentary committees. For that reason the Opposition is not at all happy about the prospect of breaching the usual rule and having this important Joint Committee sit during parliamentary sitting times. It is up to the Committee to find times which are non-sitting times in which to perform its function. The Committee has a raft of witnesses coming to Canberra. It has known about the sitting hours and about this arrangement for a long time and it is up to the Committee to make arrangements to fit in with the Parliament and not vice versa.

In view of the hour and the fact that the Senate has negatived the adjournment and given us the opportunity to debate this matter, I will not be lengthy. I say to the Government that this is but one example of the very great difficulties in which it has landed the Parliament through its pattern of sitting hours for the Senate and the House of Representatives. We do not believe it is an appropriate solution to that problem for the very appropriate and proper rules which normally preclude committees sitting during parliamentary hours to be breached.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The view of the Australian Democrats on committees meeting when the Senate is convened is relatively well known. We do not like committees to meet while the Senate is in session. There are good reasons for that and they have been rehearsed on many occasions. However, on many occasions committees have been given leave by the Senate to sit. The normal procedure is that, when a committee believes that it has an urgent matter before it, it can, after consultation generally with all members of that committee, who are from all parties, put that proposition to the Senate. The difficulty that arises is that, if the Senate is to pick and choose which committees it will allow to sit, we will have to have a much more extensive debate about whether what a committee is seeking to do is of importance. That is perhaps what we should have done long ago, but that has never been the pattern here. In fact last week I sat on a committee-the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform- which sought such leave of the Senate. Committees are meeting tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: On a number of occasions committees have met while the Senate is sitting. Generally, the Senate has judged that if a committee believes that what it is doing is serious enough for it to come to the Senate and seek leave, the Senate should give that leave. I do not believe that committees would ask leave of the Senate without due cause, and on this occasion I believe the Committee feels that it has due cause. If we are really to say no to that committee, I believe that the proper procedure would be to have a debate on what the Committee is inquiring into and then make a judgment on whether it is serious. I do not believe that that has taken place, and therefore I think we should follow the normal pattern. That is, as the Chairman has put the matter to the Senate and sought leave from the Senate for the Committee to sit because in its deliberations it has considered that it is dealing with a serious matter and needs that additional time, the Committee should be granted that leave.

TALK.START.PARA: — The situation that will arise tomorrow is an example of why committees should not sit when the Senate is sitting. Tomorrow , presumably at the same time as the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is seeking leave to sit, we will be debating in this chamber the Family Law Amendment Bill. Amendments to that Bill are quite substantive and go to the heart of a very important question for the whole of the nation about which there is to be a conscience vote-not a party vote; a conscience vote. If that matter is to be considered properly by this chamber, I believe it is incumbent upon all members of the chamber to be present or at least to have access to the debate and to know what is going on at any given time. All of us have done committee work. We know that it is not possible to concentrate on committee work and what is going on elsewhere. For that reason I am opposed to committees sitting while Parliament is also sitting. This motion is one example.

Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —By some strange coincidence I want to speak on the adjournment debate tonight on a topic that was dealt with by the Senate not so long ago; that is, East Timor. I want to speak about two aspects of that debate. The first relates to my annoyance at the arrangement whereby only Australian Labor Party speakers and Liberal Party speakers were able to debate the official report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Indonesia which is before me but on which, I know, under Standing Orders, I may not comment because debate on the report has been adjourned. We do not know when it will come before the Senate for debate again yet page after page of it calls for comment and criticism. I am annoyed that room was not made in that debate for a speaker from the Australian Democrats. I give notice that we will raise the matter again through the Whips. The situation is not tolerable. A party which is in a decisive position in voting in this Senate should have the opportunity to speak when a matter of such importance and timeliness as this is brought up for the first time. We know perfectly well that when matters of a general business nature are adjourned there is no knowing when they will come up for debate again. I will be extremely surprised, but very gratified, Mr President, if I hear that it is to be brought up again over the next few days. The Democrats were not asked to join the delegation that went to East Timor although we are the only political party in Australia, I think, which is completely united in its opposition to the events in East Timor. I believe there should be an act of self-determination.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect I want to comment on is recent events in East Timor. I think they have a great bearing on the attitudes that this Parliament and the people of this country ought to have towards the United Nations vote and the Republic of Indonesia. It is a matter of great regret that the prognostications which were made publicly early in August by me, amongst other people, that there would be another offensive by the Indonesian army into East Timor have come to pass. The information we have now is that instead of that situation being defused by the Indonesian authorities and an attempt being made at conciliation, there is renewed initiation of a massive heating up of the conflict. We do not know how much it has been heated up. Why do we not know? It is because of the censorship applying there. It is not possible for the rest of the world to know what is going on in East Timor. What methods are being used? How is this attack being made? Is it just being made against Fretilin? Is it being made against the East Timorese people as a whole? Are large numbers of people being taken away to islands and detained on the mere suspicion that they might be Fretilin sympathisers, whatever that might be, and held there without any kind of trial? It is very worrying, or should be to all of us here, in the light of that offensive, to realise also that over the last 24 hours or so there have been fresh reports of torture and intimidation of the people of East Timor and that this has been confirmed to some extent by Amnesty International.

Some time ago I met two representatives of Fretilin in Australia. They showed me photographs which turned my stomach. They were alleged to be photographs of torture carried out on East Timorese people by the Indonesian Army. The photographs could have been faked, but I looked at them pretty carefully and listened pretty well to those people and their reaction to the photographs. I can only say that for the photographs to have been other than genuine they must have been the best dissimulators in the world and the best forgers of photographs that I can imagine. But it all comes back to this: We do not know. Our larger neighbour time and time again comes to us and says: 'You must just assume that we are doing the right thing here. You are not to know what we are doing. You are not to come in and see with any fairness what we plan to do'. If tomorrow I received an invitation from the Republic of Indonesia to go to East Timor and went, perhaps with a group of my colleagues from the Senate, there would be no way in the world that I would be able to find out with any honesty what was going on there. Why not? In a place with such a history of torture and intimidation, how could I or any other person find out? I do not speak Timorese. I do not know the place. I do not have contacts there that I can talk to personally. Even if I did those people, knowing that there would be a risk of being at best imprisoned, at worst tortured or killed, the moment I left the country if they told me anything other than what the Indonesian Government wanted me to hear, would not tell me anything. Surely it would be an act of extreme naiverty on my part to assume, behind such an invitation, any proper purpose that could allow any final evaluation or statements about the situation in East Timor to come from me or colleagues visiting the place in the next month or year. Of course there is no way that that can be done.

I am here attacking a very wrong state of affairs, one of censorship, of subjugation of a whole people. I am not prepared, as are some people in this chamber, through you, Mr President, merely to have the insolence to dispose of a whole potential nation, one that would be quite capable of carrying out, and anxious to carry out, an independent and self-responsible role-a nation to which , what is more, we owe a debt of honour. But no, we wash our hands of it. We take our pieces of silver, represented by the convenience of perhaps not having a difficult relationship with our large neighbour. We make ourselves subservient to the wishes of that large neighbour, who lays down the law as to what will happen in our neighbourhood. Let me make quite plain that at no stage have I ever said that I think East Timor should be handed over to Fretilin, or that Fretilin necessarily commands the support of the people of East Timor. All that I have said, and all that I think most people who are interested in this situation have said, is that the people themselves should have the right to decide through an act of self-determination. Take that from them, take that from any people, and you take everything from them. It would be like saying to the people of this nation, 'You no longer have the right to elect members of parliament'-that Indonesia, Russia, China or America would be moving in and the new law would be that we would no longer determine our own future. We would do as we were told, otherwise we would suffer certain penalties. Indonesia has no ethnic, historic or cultural rights to East Timor. It never has had and it never will have, as far as I can see.

I should like to deal very briefly with this question of the United Nations vote shortly to come, because I think it is of major importance. Some people have argued, and I think it is a dangerous analogy, that it is pro-communist for us to support this right of self-determination in East Timor. They argue that if Australia or anybody else for that matter were to vote in favour of East Timor that would be voting in line with communist ideology. But when one looks at the pattern of the voting on East Timor, one sees that most of the Eastern bloc countries either absent themselves or abstain. That point is worth getting into the record. It is true of countries such as Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Romania. It is true that in 1982 Russia and China voted in favour of East Timor. But let us have a look at the other side of the argument. If we are to accept the argument of guilt by association, who then become our partners in crime? Argentina, El Salvador, Guatemala and Chile all voted in favour of Indonesia. One is led to ask what these countries have in common. They all, of course, have appalling records in the field of human rights and a number are autocracies which would certainly tend to agree with the idea that it is perfectly all right to take over a small neighbour and subjugate it as far as one wishes.

There are in this chamber those who say that those of us who press for self- determination for East Timor are carrying out a wrong action because we are giving the people there who are resisting Indonesian occupation false hope, hope of more support than they perhaps would get. I made it quite plain, I might say, when I discussed this matter with the Fretilin people I met in Melbourne that that was not the case, that indeed there was no way in which I would support or encourage any kind of aid from outside or any sort of mischief or meddling, especially the supply of arms or anything else of that sort to Fretilin. I asked the Fretilin people: 'Can you tell me where your arms have come from? Have you ever been supplied with arms from outside your country?' They said 'No'. I said: 'I have no way of establishing the truth of that but at least you and I are on common ground. There is no way you should do that. Your struggle is your own but beyond that your right to carry it out is your own'. When people in the rest of the world say that that must be taken from them I think we get a distortion of principle which we might very well search our souls to examine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the adjournment to suggest to the Government that it might indulge in a little open government and in a useful way involve the broader public in some of the policy considerations that it is at present discussing with the States. The Government has made a number of promises, some would say threats, to introduce a resource rental tax in Australia. In this chamber the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, has gone to some trouble to explain the theoretical basis of that tax and why in the Government's view it is a method of taxing mining profits that is superior to the miscellany of charges which the industry bears at present. Those arguments do have some theoretical appeal. One can very easily , I think, make out a case that taxes on profits are more likely to encourage investments than taxes on gross which will be paid whether the particular project is making a profit or very much profit.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation in which the Government is, in very broad terms, describing a quite new taxing regime that it would like to introduce. That general proposition is one which, in the view of the Opposition, is giving rise to a considerable uncertainty in the industries which are apparently to be the subject of the new tax, namely the, oil and coal industries. The sort of uncertainties about which I find people are concerned relate to such questions as the level of profit, the threshold at which the tax would begin to be payable ; the rate of tax that might be payable; whether one is to have a multiple threshold; whether the tax might be assessed on a project basis; whether it is to be a replacement tax, as described by Senator Walsh and, if so, what it is replacing and on what basis it is to replace State charges; who is to administer the tax; how is it to be administered, and so on.

I must say that from the examination of the public statements made by the Government and from the available material that I have access to one in hard pressed to know in what form any tax might emerge. This is a time of some uncertainty in industry, although the oil industry is going through a period of great optimism over the last few days because of some very good drilling results . I think that the Minister would agree that it is a time of uncertainty and some difficulty for both the coal and oil industries. The declining real world price of oil is one factor. With respect to the coal industry the rather shrunken market is a factor. I would have thought it would have been generally accepted that speculation about the future tax arrangements for those industries must add to the uncertainties which are economically destructive.

The Government, very sensibly, is engaging the State governments which are, of course, very closely involved with this because many of the taxes are State taxes. I understand from media reports and from some discussions which I have had that the Government has gone to the mining Ministers of the States. It has held discussions with them on this subject. The Government has undertaken to come back to the mining Ministers and produce a further paper and further information and advice to ensure that there can be further productive discussion between the Commonwealth and the States. I commend that course of action which is being followed by the Government. It is enimently sensible and fits in with the statements which have been made by the Minister who is presently in the Senate and by other Government spokesmen that the tax would not be introduced without the co-operation of the States. Again, it is not quite clear how far that statement goes, but it has been made. The suggestion which I wish to make to the Minister in the chamber this evening is that there could be value for the Government, the community and the industry if the sort of consultation which the Government is undertaking could be widened.

It appears to me that if the sort of information which is being made available to the States could be made available publicly so that the industry itself could examine some of the possibilities which are being considered, so that academics may have a chance to consider, comment and advise, and so that the Opposition may have a chance to consider, advise and join in the discussion, it would be of value. I think that the Minister would agree that it is possible not only for oppositions to make mistakes, but also for governments to make them. In the recent Budget rejigging which occurred with respect to the change in excise duties there was a simple example of how calculations put before a government by its public servants proved to require revision. Those sorts of errors can be made in any government. The fact is that the issues are complicated and at times the relevant questions simply will not be asked. Hence the right answers will not be arrived at. I think that the potential of the resource rent tax to disrupt severely these major resource industries is such that it is in the interests of Australia that any propositions be given the most careful and, indeed, public consideration so that the widest possible contribution can be made to the process.

I have found in the community, the industry, and academic world a very considerable interest in the broad approaches which have been outlined by the Government. I have found almost universally a stated inability to come to grips with the substance of the Government's proposals because not enough detail is known. Therefore, I make a very earnest suggestion to the Government that it widen its dissemination of information. Some of the indicative figuring, for example, which must have been undertaken to try to work out how the sort of balance that Senator Walsh described in very general terms can be achieved between what is being raised now and what is sought to be raised, could be made generally available. I think all of this could usefully be exposed not only to the Opposition, but also to the public and those other people who could make a contribution. Rather than my setting out a great series of questions on the Notice Paper, which would be simply a great waste of time and effort for many of the bureaucrats that would be put to work answering them, I wish to make a general suggestion to the Government that it make available information which I know it is making available to State goverments and which will be part of its own material in trying to arrive at decisions on what I regard as a very difficult administrative, economic and political problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking briefly in reply I should set one matter unequivocally on the record. The Government is committed to the replacement of the existing crude oil levy in the 1984-85 financial year by a resources rent tax. Such a tax would remove the distinction between new and old oil as I, both in government and opposition, have stated. My predecessor in opposition, Paul Keating, did also. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has also stated this publicly on several occasions recently. On reflection I am not sure that he did explicitly state it recently. In addition to removing the distinction between new and old oil, such a tax would be applied on a project cash flow basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also believes that there is a compelling argument for the extension of the same taxation concept to some other areas. It is very much easier to do in the case of oil because more than 90 per cent of the oil presently produced is in what is constitutionally Commonwealth territory. That does not apply to other minerals and the States have the primary taxing right and therefore the power, should they choose to do so, effectively to pre-empt the introduction of rent based taxes by levying high levels of other taxes and charges so that, in effect, there would be no rent left to tax in any case. The Commonwealth is in a position to proceed with the taxation of oil. In the case of other minerals we hope to persuade other governments to adopt similar policies, at least to some extent.

In response to Senator Chaney's proposal, I do not believe, and I do not think any of my colleagues believe, that all the original or rational thought in this Parliament is on the Government side or that all the people who are capable of original or rational thought and analysis are on the Government side. There are a number in the Opposition. I think Senator Chaney might well make a useful contribution to the discussion on this subject. Senator Peter Rae would be another useful contributor. I am not suggesting that that is an exhaustive list. I think there are some who probably are not capable of making a useful or rational contribution, but I will not speculate about who they might be. Therefore, the Government and I would welcome constructive comment and criticism which the Opposition might care to offer. The very broad, very general paper presented to the Australian Minerals and Energy Council meeting on 1 June this year is available to members of the Opposition from my office if they wish to pick up a copy if they do not already have it.

As far as I am concerned members of the Opposition are welcome to access to subsequent discussion papers. I should, however, lodge this caveat: At some stage the proposals will become specific enough to influence, for example, the price of shares in particular enterprises. Obviously at that stage-I am sure Senator Chaney would appreciate this-that sort of information has to be very closely held. It would be quite improper to have it available to some people who could either directly or inadvertently make it available to others who could use it for commercial gain in a way that is not proper. In accepting Senator Chaney' s proposal that the consultation be as wide as possible and include the Opposition, I believe that one of the potential advantages to be gained is a stable tax regime. The Government desires it to be stable. Obviously, the chances of its being stable are better if there has been a significant degree of bipartisan involvement and, hopefully, bipartisan support. As Senator Chaney probably knows, an interdepartmental committee was set up some time ago to examine this matter. The work of that committee has been slowed down severely by Budget matters which have occupied the time of most of the tax expertise within the Commonwealth bureaucracy.

I have made a number of statements in the Senate in answer to questions. Comments, although of a general type, have been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others. I have also made comments to industry representatives. My own thoughts were pretty concisely summarised in a letter in today's Australian Financial Review. As the letter states, they are to be regarded as general guidelines. However, they are more specific than many people obviously were aware. I would like to add one point to the Australian Financial Review summary. I have said to industry representatives that I am sure they would be astounded if a government, in designing a tax regime with threshold rates of return and rates of tax, introduced a replacement tax regime which yielded significantly less revenue from Bass Strait than do the existing levy arrangements.

Therefore, that is one of the reasons why I have suggested that a multiple threshold would, in association with a progressive rate of tax within a single tax regime, accommodate that revenue requirement which the Government has from Bass Strait without imposing what might be seen as excessive levels of taxation on other oil fields in Australia, particularly the potential oil fields because, in spite of the promising new discovery to which Senator Chaney has referred, the overwhelming weight of geological opinion is that the prospects, of finding another oil field comparable to Bass Strait both in its absolute size and the ease and low cost with which the oil can be extracted, are somewhat remote. Senator Chaney has been kind enough to provide me with a copy of today's Australian Financial Review. In closing I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter to which I referred.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
SIR, In his article on oil taxation (AFR, September 1), Rick Wilkinson makes two assertions on which I should comment.
(1) ''A rent tax would not achieve tax neutrality and it would have an adverse effect on investment decisions.''

Company tax, State royalties or any other tax have an adverse effect on investment decisions, relative to no tax at all. A no-tax regime, however, does not exist and never has existed. The choice is between different types of tax.
A rent tax has the unique advantage of imposing no tax on marginal production or marginal prospects. Therefore, it goes closer to achieving ''Tax neutrality'' than any alternative.
(2) ''The major ground for industry resistance has not been addressed by Senator Walsh in any of his public utterances on the subject.''

I and other members of the Government, both in Government and Opposition, have always said that a rent tax would not be introduced without adequate consultation with the oil industry and other interested parties on matters of detail and administration. However, the broad outlines of our proposal have been stated publicly and privately on many occasions. We have proposed:
A rent tax should replace the existing levy system.
It should be project-based.
It should be cash-flow based; that is, it would not apply until net earnings have exceeded total investment.
It would not apply until return on shareholders' funds have exceeded a threshold rate of return.
It seems desirable to have multiple thresholds combined with a progressive rate .
Some allowance for failed exploration activity should be incorporated.
In addition to the no tax on marginal production advantage, a rent tax, compared to a levy system, has these investment benefits:
It will not adversely affect early cash flows.
It will automatically compensate for the high costs of finding and producing oil from small fields and difficult or remote locations; that is, the type of oil most likely to be found in Australia.

Finally, Rick Wilkinson notes that a company could be required to pay a ( project-based) rent tax even if the company as a whole was making losses. That could be so. It could also happen under the existing levy system.
PETER WALSH Minister For Resources and Energy. Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have 500 people died so far of 1,300 cases in the USA of a previously unknown, so far inexplicable, and incurable disease known as AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome), a disease of the body's immune system, and is it reported that no-one who has been infected has yet recovered from it.

(2) Is the Minister for Health aware that cases have recently been reported also in Denmark, France and Germany, and that while most cases occur among homosexual men and intravenous drug users of both sexes, it is now spreading to the partners and children of these people, and also has been transmitted to recipients of blood transfusions.

(3) Is it now suspected that, due to a latent and potentially infectious phase of this disease (as long as two years), it is regarded as having a major potential for spreading, and that in the United States a major growth in the number of cases has been predicted.
(4) Has the disease been reported in Australia.
(5) Has the Minister for Health taken steps to see that this disease is identified, notified and monitored if it occurs in Australia.

(6) Has the Minister for Health sought the co-operation of the medical profession in reporting early symptoms, described as severe weight loss, fatigue , fever, swollen glands, and persistent virus infection, leading to amongst other things, lung inflammation, fungal throat infection, severe multiple infections, and purple-red bruise-like spots on the limbs.
(7) If no action has been taken on this matter, can it be taken as soon as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to recent reports received from the USA over 450 persons have died from AIDS.
Although patients may recover from the particular episode of infection, their immune deficiency remains unaltered and they are therefore vulnerable to further infections.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes. One confirmed case reported in Australia to date.

(5) and (6) Yes. The Department of Health through the Communicable Diseases Intelligence Bulletin, which has a wide professional distribution, has drawn attention to AIDS in No. 81/15 of 31 July 1981, No. 82/16 of 13 August 1982, No. 82/24 of 3 December 1982. In Bulletin No. 83/8 of 22 April 1983 it specifically requested information related to any occurrences of this group of diseases to be notified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will a minimum fee apply to community child care.
(2) How many places does the Minister anticipate will be taken up by the elimination of the $10 minimum fee proposed by the former Government.

(3) Which departments are involved in the Interdepartmental Committee undertaking a review of the fee relief arrangements for child care, and (a) who is the Chairman, and (b) who are the officers involved in this Interdepartmental Committee.
(4) When and where will community consultation, mentioned in the Minister for Social Security's press release of 29 March 1983, occur.
(5) Has the Department of Social Security or any other department undertaken studies of users of various child care facilities.
(6) What studies have taken place on users of: (a) non-profit based, (b) profit based, and (c) home care child care facilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 29 March 1983, I announced that the minimum fee proposed by the previous Government would be dropped from the Commonwealth funding guidelines for day care fee relief which were to be introduced on 1 April 1983.

(2) The proposal to drop the minimum fee was based on the assumption that 7 per cent of places, or just over 2,000 places, would be utilised by families eligible for maximum Commonwealth fee relief support.

(3) (a) and (b) The departments involved in the Interdepartmental Committee requested to review fee relief arrangements for child care were the departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Finance, and Social Security (Chair). A number of officers in each department were involved in the normal course of their duties.

(4) Community consultation on day care funding arrangements throughout 1983 will, and have, taken a number of forms. Firstly, I and my department have taken particular note of the range of comments, letters and submissions received on the arrangements. Secondly, I have approached a national co-ordinating agency to hold a consultation forum on fee relief for day care. The details of this consultation are yet to be finalised.

(5) and (6) Studies have been undertaken by my department and by State and Territory departments on the users of child care services. The most comprehensive of these were censuses, in 1980, 1981 and 1982 of licensed and/or supervised pre-school and child care services which sought data on the characteristics of each service, its staff and the children attending. These censuses, known as the 'National Data Base Collection', were jointly designed and administered by the Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities with responsibilities for the services, together with the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Data is available to all authorities involved. My department has released summary statistics of the findings, has undertaken a number of specific studies using the data to support the development and administration of the Children's Services Program, and proposes further analysis of the date as part of its research program.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics collects and publishes statistics from its Child Care Arrangements survey the most recent of which was in 1980 and covered all child care arrangements by the families surveyed.

In addition to these, studies have been undertaken of specific services or services in specific locations. Some of these have been under the Children's Services Program, administered by my department.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force: Cleaning of Fuel Tanks

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the name of the solvent prepared by the Royal Australian Air Force for cleaning the interior of fuel tanks of F111 aircraft.
(2) What are its chemical constituents.

(3) What methods are used to clean inside F111 fuel tanks and are RAAF personnel responsible for physically cleaning them; if so, (a) are RAAF personnel required to completely enter the F111 fuel tanks to apply chemical solvents, (b) what measures are taken to protect personnel from chemical contact and (c) what danger does close contact with such solvent pose to human health.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are several solvents which have been used by the RAAF for cleaning the interior of F111 aircraft fuel tanks, known respectively as SR51, SR51A, GD500 and Part No ME767. None of these solvents is prepared by the RAAF. The latter solvent Part ME767, which is a general cleaning solvent and used for cleaning and surface preparation prior to periodic resealing of fuel tanks, is prepared by the Maribyrnong Explosive Factory Victoria. SR51, SR51A and GD500, which were used in conjunction with chemical operations to remove the sealant in the tanks for a complete resealing operation on all F111 aircraft completed earlier this year, are prepared by the Eldorado Chemical Company, USA.
(2) (a) The chemical constituents of SR51 are:
(i) Thiophenol, 10-20 per cent parts by volume
(ii) Pyrrolidone, 5-10 per cent parts by volume
(iii) Triethyl phosphate, 1-5 per cent parts by volume
(iv) Naphtha, remainder
(b) The chemical constituents of SR51A are:
(i) Thiophenol, 40 per cent parts by volume
(ii) Pyrrolidone, 10 per cent parts by volume
(iii) Naphtha, 50 per cent parts by volume
(c) The chemical constituents of GD500 are:
(i) Ethylene glycol monobutyl ether-5 per cent parts by volume
(ii) Monophenol polyethylene glycol-9 per cent parts by volume
(iii) Sodium dodecyl benzene sulphonate-7 per cent parts by volume
(iv) Distilled water-79 per cent parts by volume.
(d) The chemical constituents of Part No ME767 are:
(i) Aromatic naphtha-50 per cent parts by volume
(ii) Ethyl acetate-20 per cent parts by volume
(iii) Methyl ethyl ketone-20 per cent parts by volume
(iv) Isopropyl alcohol-10 per cent parts by volume.

(3) Use of solvents SR51, SR51A, and GD500 during the complete resealing operation was carried out utilizing a pumping operation and did not require personnel to enter the fuel tanks for this phase of the programme. Part No ME767 is applied by rubbing the tank surface with cheese-cloth moistened with the solvent. RAAF personnel are required to physically carry out this task.
(a) In the case of SR51, SR51A and GD500 personnel were not required to enter the fuel tanks, but are required to do so to apply Part No ME767

(b) During all chemical processes, including cleaning, associated with removing tank sealant and subsequent resealing operations, all personnel in the immediate area are required to wear protective clothing including gloves and goggles as a protective measure against chemical contact. In addition, while personnel are inside the fuel tanks, conditioned air is pumped into the tanks to reduce fuel and solvent concentrations. At the same time safety workers are stationed outside each tank. When large cleaning operations are carried out, workers are rotated through cleaning and sealing duties.

(c) Information on the toxicities of the cleaning solvents is not available from the manufacturers. However, in such cases the safety procedures adopted by the RAAF involve treating the chemical mixture as being at least as toxic as the most toxic individual chemical in the mixture. Appropriate safety equipment and procedures are then applied to prevent danger to human health. It is considered that the safety measures described at 3b. above fulfil this purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 1 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is it inappropriate to provide names of people allocated work by the Telephone Interpreter Service in South Australia in view of the fact that these people are in receipt of public moneys (see answers to Question No. 21, Hansard 24 May 1983, page 742).
(2) Who decides which persons are placed on the panel of contract interpreters and what are the guidelines used.
(3) How many persons have not been included on the panel.

(4) Does the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs keep statements of all moneys paid to individuals under this program for audit and annual budgetary services; if not, why not; and if so why could those details not be provided in answer to Question No. 21.
(5) How many hours of research is anticipated to take to provide the information requested, in Question No. 21 and in the previous parts of this Question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My earlier decision not to provide names of people allocated work by the Telephone Interpreter Service and the amount of their earnings was based mainly on the need to respect their personal privacy. While I appreciate that these persons are in receipt of public moneys, this in itself is not a criterion for publication of their names. A further factor is that it would have incurred considerable cost (in staff time) to analyse cost data on the thousands of interpreting jobs allocated each year in South Australia. This would inevitably have reduced staff time available for the provision of services.

(2) My Department decides which persons are placed on the panel of contract interpreters. Applications are invited both through direct contact, and through public advertisement. Preference is given to applicants possessing level II or higher accreditation by the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters (NAATI). Applicants are also assessed against other appropriate criteria, including qualifications, experience and a capacity to work effectively under pressure.
(3) My Department does not keep an aggregate record of unsuccessful applicants.

(4) My Department keeps records of all interpreter assignments under the TIS program and the total costs involved. The resources required do not justify the preparation of a detailed breakdown of these payments. In addition, I would not be prepared to authorise the publication of such details without the consent of those to whom the payments were made.
(5) It has been estimated that it would take a junior clerk three person months at a cost of $3,250.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 3 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Federal Government make representations to the Chilean Government expressing Australia's abhorrence to descriptions in the latest Amnesty International report on Chile which details gruesome methods of torture and press for an open inquiry into these torture allegations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has noted the Amnesty International report to which the honourable senator has referred and is disturbed by its implications.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bill Hayden, made clear Australia's concern about the unrepresentative character of the Pinochet regime and its disregard for fundamental human rights, notably freedom of association and expression, in a statement on 16 June 1983. In addition officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs have made representations to the Chilean authorities concering specific situations which have arisen including during the days of national protest which have taken place in Chile in recent months.

The United Nations General Assembly and the Commission on Human Rights continuously monitor human rights developments in Chile. Australia has lent its full support to strongly worded resolutions adopted by those bodies. The Government regards the Commission on Human Rights as an effective force in efforts to convince the Chilean Government to respect the human rights of its citizens and we will continue to support that body in its investigative procedures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the Defence Department fail to designate HMAS Sydney with 'Special Duty' status as defined in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1963 despite the fact that between 1965 and 1972 the HMAS Sydney entered a 'Special Area' 24 times.
(2) Why did the Defence Department insist the HMAS Sydney had to be subjected to continuous danger which is a departure from the definition outlined in the Act.

(3) Why was the HMAS Sydney placed on a high state of damage control readiness which became more frequent as it came closer to its destination if the Defence Department believed the ship was not in continuous danger.
(4) Why does the Defence Department believe a ship performing logistical and supply duties, as the HMAS Sydney was, to be in less danger than ships performing other tasks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) HMAS Sydney was not allotted for special duty under the Repatriation ( Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 because her voyages to Vietnam were of a transitory nature only. She did not remain there for operational duty.

(2) In July 1965 the Government decided that allotment for special duty should only be made when personnel were exposed to potential risk by reason of the fact there was a continuing danger from activities of hostile forces. To accord with this decision personnel on duty in 'special areas' such as staff visits or other occurrences of a short term nature were not eligible for allotment for special duty. The complements of ships or aircraft engaged on conveying or escorting duties to or from 'special areas' were similarly not eligible for allotment.

(3) HMAS Sydney's armament and sensor systems were manned while she transited coastal waters off Vietnam and when at anchor. These measures were taken as precautions against any enemy action that might eventuate. However the limited period so involved did not meet the concept of a continuing danger envisaged in the Government's policy decision at (2) above.

(4) Ships performing logistical or supply duties such as Sydney were in Vietnam waters for relatively short periods, one to three days in the case of HMAS Sydney; in performing these duties they were not directly engaged in warlike operations as provided for in the definition of 'Special Duty' in the Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1983 (Hansard, page 157), Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the women's emergency services program.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
An amount of $4m will be provided by the Federal Government in 1983-84 for a women's emergency services program.

The program will include $200,000 earmarked for ethnic workers to assist migrant residents of refuges. This allocation is in recognition of the particular language and cultural difficulties faced by women from non-English speaking backgrounds in crisis situations.

The Government's aim will be to co-ordinate provision of emergency services for women and children escaping from intolerable domestic situations, in co- operation with the States and community groups.

Commonwealth support for crisis accommodation, including youth refuges and shelter for the chronically homeless is currently under review. Detailed decisions about administration and funding of the proposed women's emergency services program will be made in the context of that review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.
